text_content: My original orientation once was, â€œthe closer I can get to something or someone, the more involved, integral, and exposed, the better.â€ I was born into a world I wanted to merge with, to meld into. Everything seemed so rich, so beautiful, so fascinating. I just wanted to know it all, intimately, from the inside out. This included things, like VCRs and toys, but also people, too.As Iâ€™ve grown, Iâ€™ve learned to not be so ferocious in my hunger for this, but I suspect itâ€™s still very much there. The call of the void looks different for every person, I imagine, but for me it still looks like wanting to be subsumed.But now... seeing the impossibility of the chemical and alchemical work involved in producing a â€œperfect meldâ€ â€” seeing the nuances of incompatibility of things and people, and indeed, of everything in this world. My friendâ€™s music preferences clash with mine; the hoops I need to jump through for clients feel arbitrary; my bed doesnâ€™t match my aesthetic.

text_content: Maybe these worlds are not made to merge. Maybe they exists as they do due to the interplay of things, people, and egregores. Maybe our inborn goal isnâ€™t to find a â€œperfect,â€ final fit, but to find a million and one â€œdynamic,â€ intermediate fits. Stable orbits, if you will.What does that mean, specifically? In a relationship, I might be tempted to figure out how to spend more time with the person, meet them on every level, seek their connection on all of my levels, etc. But maybe I can learn to hold the desire, the longing, and let the roots and vines grow gradually, over time. Maybe I neednâ€™t over-plan or over-tend. Gaps and spaces are where the relationship can let light and air in, to grow.Iâ€™m guessing itâ€™s the same for work and life. Do I need these things to fit so perfectly, or is the feeling of dissonance and discord a flicker of a sign that there is more to see and do? Is a â€œperfect fitâ€ now or forever a false idol?

text_content: And the kicker is that it all came to a head, this year. I had put on so many hats over my lifetime, and they were all stacked up neatly on my head that the weight was crushing me. And as I started to take them off, the process changed my personality. It changed my expression. It changed my set point. And I truly believed that I was uncovering â€œtrue Joshuaâ€ and that the result would be finally finding who I am, once and for all, and that I would enter a new era of confidence and authenticity.And now I see that was... almost right.Itâ€™s clear to me that there is no need to be â€œthat guyâ€ or â€œthis girl.â€ Thereâ€™s no need to fashion a coherent identity, or to stabilize preferences over time, or even to hold or let go of preferences. The â€œtrue Joshuaâ€ is probably closer to the one who has let go of this project, and who allows himself to accept and acknowledge that his identity is fundamentally, fluid, reflective, and transient, and that this isnâ€™t a deficit.

And the kicker is that it all came to a head, this year. I had put on so many hats over my lifetime, and they were all stacked up neatly on my head that the weight was crushing me. And as I started to take them off, the process changed my personality. It changed my expression. It changed my set point. And I truly believed that I was uncovering â€œtrue Joshuaâ€ and that the result would be finally finding who I am, once and for all, and that I would enter a new era of confidence and authenticity.

And now I see that was... almost right.

Itâ€™s clear to me that there is no need to be â€œthat guyâ€ or â€œthis girl.â€ Thereâ€™s no need to fashion a coherent identity, or to stabilize preferences over time, or even to hold or let go of preferences. The â€œtrue Joshuaâ€ is probably closer to the one who has let go of this project, and who allows himself to accept and acknowledge that his identity is fundamentally, fluid, reflective, and transient, and that this isnâ€™t a deficit.

text_content: Somebody just liked my post, Contingency Diagrams. Looking back at it, I think I can remember the frame of mind I was in when I wrote it. Backed up, desperate for change. I think most of that came from a cyclical pattern of life I was stuck inâ€”telling myself I had to deal with the house, find a job, improve my health and patterns.Well, I found a job. I got an offer from a YC startup that Iâ€™m actually really keen on. I flew out and met the guys and spent half a day coding (with AI, which was strange), whiteboarding, and discussing product. At the end of the day, I came away excited about their opportunities. This is a clutch time for them, and the scaling that will be unlocked with the next few hires is going to be monumental. Thereâ€™s clear value, product-market-fit, and a lot of interesting avenues to explore. And these guys are executers, not pie-in-the-sky pontificators. It bodes well. And hey, they seemed to really like me and my approach, too! ğŸ™ğŸ¼That job is now a forcing function for the rest of my life. I have two weeks to do whatever I need to do out here before I fly down there for a week of onboarding. Iâ€™ll then have three more weeks to finalize everything out here before moving there and working from the office with them, full time. Whew! What a change!

text_content: Part of me is super excited for it. I realize now that subjecting oneself to new environments and circumstances can reshape us (how could it not?). At the same time, itâ€™s a little daunting to go from my cocoon of self-discovery and introspection, in which Iâ€™ve been trying to find myself, absent of external forces and demands, to an new, potentially chaotic and demanding environment, in which a lot of the room Iâ€™ve enjoyed (and perhaps squandered), will be gone. The only way to know what the right decision is is to make one. And betting on change can be a good bet, even when youâ€™re not sure of the odds. If you donâ€™t like your results, change your laboratory. Or something.Anyway, all of that is well and good. The die is cast. Unless something completely unforeseeable happens, I will be on my way.And thatâ€™s the crux of this post. I made this decision, pursued this path, and now it kind of invalidates a lot of what I was saying in the other post. I mean, I did and do need to recover, but through traveling to SF for the interview, and hanging out with friends, I have found that my capacity isnâ€™t as low as I thought. A lot has changed about how I carry myself and what occupies my mind, and even what I valueâ€”a lot of the thoughts that said I need my life to be a certain way or have certain things in it have quieted down. So... maybe I didnâ€™t need six months. I just needed to move through it. I donâ€™t know, actually.

text_content: That brings me to the other thing. I met someone. Well, I was introduced to someone, through a mutual friend. We took it slowly at first, just hanging out and getting to know each other, but after spending a good amount of time together, it became clear that we go well together. Itâ€™s something in the nature of the energy and communication. She has a way about her that I adore. It feels a bit strange talking about the details, as they feel personal. Suffice to say, spending time in her presence has made me doubt the importance of some of my earlier judgements. For instance, the house that felt so stifling and isolated, felt completely fine and even pleasant with her there. Iâ€™ve never faced anything like this before. It feels like an underspecified trolly problem. Could we incubate our relationship over long-distance? Would it last? Should I look for another job? What if the role doesnâ€™t quite feel like a sustainable fit for some reason? Will we just have to fly back and forth every month? Will we even prove to be compatible in the long term, separation or not? Ugh!

text_content: Do you crave connection? Do you want to be seen? Understood? Met? Do you want to feel less alone in your thoughts?The image these questions bring to mind is when something weird or unexpected happens and your eyes scan the crowd, lock with a strangerâ€™s, and you and they exchange a knowing glance. â€œDid you see that?!â€ Your eyes inquire. â€œGoodness! Yes,â€ theirs reply. No words, just a momentary lookâ€”maybe a changed expression; a laugh, a smile, or a sturgeon.That may be the simplest, clearest, and most commonplace form of connection that I can think of. Obviously we can talk, fight, make love, and dance. So many activities bring us close together, weaving our experience with anotherâ€™s, through space, time, or mind. But most of the things we do together, if not all, tend to involve us juggling the contact and the concept. We are multitaskingâ€”attending to the experience and the intermittent jabber of our mindâ€™s commentary.

text_content: â€œThe lookâ€ cuts through all of that. Our eyes search for a felt resonance, telegraphing their own immediacy and presence with the way they scan the crowd. I imagine they dart across faces with micro movements that betray exactly what weâ€™re looking for: mutual recognition. The timing and urgency, the facial expression, the body positioningâ€”all of these serve as coordination cues hinting at the event that set us off.Anyway, I love those moments. Those pauses make me feel so unalone. I donâ€™t seek them, but when I stumble on them I always wish for more. How about you?It became clear to me that Iâ€™ve held this experience in such high regardâ€”not those moments per se, but the felt sensation of that unaloneness, triggered by those and other similar moments of mutual pauseâ€”that I created an unnecessary binary, in which the unconnected moments are distinctly lacking that beautiful quality. But is that real? Is it? Well, kinda. Itâ€™s like if I tell you â€œbe aware of your breathing.â€ Were you thinking about it a minute ago? Probably not. But now it trips you up, if only slightly, no? Same thing with the sense of aloneness or separation. In my case, I had created such a habitual longing for connection that I would feel that lack even when it wasnâ€™t a problem! What a ripoff!

text_content: The knot loosened a bit when I reflected on the nature of the desire. Essentially, itâ€™s pointing me towards merging, or a sense of absolute connection with an â€œother.â€ But... if I merged with an other, then weâ€™d just be one. And the object of the longing would be gone. Or the subject of the longing. Either way, itâ€™s a paradox! There is no perfect connected state, as my mind has constructed it. There canâ€™t be. As this came into view, I relaxed a bit. I could see how the spectrum of connection, even the apparent â€œfactâ€ of connection (are we connected or not; how connected are we, etc.) is a spiral of infinite regress. The efforts to determine the level of connection themselves create the sense of distance, the evaluation is a moving targetâ€”as soon as we start looking, we stop connecting; evaluating â€œare we connectedâ€ is orthogonal to actually connecting, and doing so has us chasing our tail, circling moments that have already ended, dropping the ball on the actual connection. Hilarious!So now Iâ€™m just trying to explore the experience by feeling. What is the possible â€œstate spaceâ€ of connection? In what ways am I connected to those around me (especially the ones my traditional rubric would say that Iâ€™m not)? In what ways is the syncopated disharmony of disconnection a form of connecting in itself? Where is the limit to harmony, the edge? Can I find each in the other?

text_content: As I was deleting old emails, I came across one for Living with Idea Addiction. I havenâ€™t watched it in a while (I usually skim through those recordings after I upload, and only rarely rewatch them after that). Still, I remember more broadly the gist of that and the subsequent conversations we had. I recall explaining the nature of my addiction to ideas and to trying to make sense of the world, which was probably clear to see from the recordings themselves, even if I hadnâ€™t been so explicitly self-analyzing. But that pattern feels a bit further off, now. I think the addiction is has actually been broken.Defender and I havenâ€™t recorded a call in a over a month, now. Heâ€™s busy running an in-person get together, and Iâ€™ve been buckling down looking for my next job. Iâ€™ve spent less time engaging on Twitter, and less time trying to make sense of or articulate my experience. I wonâ€™t presume to speak for him, but it does seem like weâ€™ve both transitioned from that phase. For me, the idea of making sense of or scheming to â€œfixâ€ the world carries much less appeal. Actually, if Iâ€™m honest, Iâ€™m not interested in that at all. Iâ€™d love for my actions to benefit others, and mankind in general. Iâ€™d be grateful to see reality more clearly and to understand whatâ€™s going on and why. That sounds nice. But I seem to be drawn away from those goals as explicit targets of my conscious efforts. Even writing this now to try to explain this feels... pointless.

text_content: You are exhausted from a lifetime of adaptive over-functioning, and your nervous system no longer believes that trying harder will lead to safety, love, or meaning.What looks like â€œkeeping options openâ€ is actually a bid for physiological permission to stop â€” without triggering catastrophe.It was clear to me that this was quite true, and that my eagerness to get out of here and get back to â€œreal lifeâ€ was insulating me from what Iâ€™ve really needed all along: rest. Consistent, persistent rest.I put together a new graph:A simplified graph with present-moment decisions, centered around giving me the space I need to truly unfurl.I have a sense that this looks like a defeat, and in a way, it is. But this is what I need right now. The real story hereâ€”or at least, the one I care aboutâ€”is that I used a graph in a novel way and it helped me cut through the cyclical patterns of thought I was stuck in. Thatâ€™s a win!

text_content: I donâ€™t have any new points to write about, actually. Life has been pretty monotonous since my last post. The insights donâ€™t matter to me, anymore, either. text_content: And now Iâ€™m sitting in a half-empty house. Two of the three bedrooms are empty. My living room is dark. My dining table only has a bench next to it; the chairs are gone. Something about this feels limiting. Iâ€™ve felt it in my body. I feel tired, achey, lethargic. I struggle to motivate myself to go through all of the motions my mind has set out for me to go through. People call me and I reluctantly answer the phone. Iâ€™d rather sleep in.But, in the midst of this, little tidbits are dropping out. I talked to my mom and realized that my desire to meet others in agenda-less presence is probably entirely bottlenecked on my ability to meet myself in agenda-less presence. I talked to Defender and realized that nearly everything my mind thinks is colored by a subconscious desire to engineer my way to truth, connection, and abundance. I talked to my daughter and laughed about how restless I get when I sit down to learn, realizing that it may finally be time for me to clear space and time for me to do so.I sketched out a three-part motivational mechanism, which tracks quite clearly with my upbringing. The sophistication of the strategies and complexity of the mental structures dedicated to these motivations has only increased with time, as Iâ€™ve pruned unsuccessful strategies.

text_content: Iâ€™ve been on a kick, lately. I have wanted to change my life in significant ways. Getting out of my house is one of those ways. Iâ€™ve written about that a few times. I made the most of this place, and I donâ€™t feel at home here. Thereâ€™s a lot of aspects of it I donâ€™t like.1 And yet... Iâ€™m still here.Iâ€™ve already decided to get out. Iâ€™ve committed to getting rid of the excess stuff. Iâ€™ve started to do that, actually. And even as Iâ€™m doing that, Iâ€™m realizing... I still kind of need this place. I feel like Iâ€™m in a local minima, and getting out of here isnâ€™t going to be as simple as just selling off all of my stuff, moving out of here, and getting engaged in someplace and something new. I have to work with what Iâ€™ve got. In this case, it means reconditioning myself to have good habits that support me and my life. Sleep, exercise, diet, and work habits. I want to get those locked in. I want to feel what it feels like to have a stable routine, a stable system.It reminds me of that viral video of the teacher illustrating how to structure oneâ€™s life. The takeaway of the video is to focus on â€œfamily, friends, health, and passions,â€ but I think the takeaway for me is even closer than that. html_content:
Iâ€™ve been on a kick, lately. I have wanted to change my life in significant ways. Getting out of my house is one of those ways. Iâ€™ve written about that a few times. I made the most of this place, and I donâ€™t feel at home here. Thereâ€™s a lot of aspects of it I donâ€™t like.1 And yet... Iâ€™m still here.

Iâ€™ve already decided to get out. Iâ€™ve committed to getting rid of the excess stuff. Iâ€™ve started to do that, actually. And even as Iâ€™m doing that, Iâ€™m realizing... I still kind of need this place. I feel like Iâ€™m in a local minima, and getting out of here isnâ€™t going to be as simple as just selling off all of my stuff, moving out of here, and getting engaged in someplace and something new. I have to work with what Iâ€™ve got. In this case, it means reconditioning myself to have good habits that support me and my life. Sleep, exercise, diet, and work habits. I want to get those locked in. I want to feel what it feels like to have a stable routine, a stable system.

It reminds me of that viral video of the teacher illustrating how to structure oneâ€™s life. The takeaway of the video is to focus on â€œfamily, friends, health, and passions,â€ but I think the takeaway for me is even closer than that. The golf balls are way closer to homeâ€”sleep, nutrition, exercise, focus. If I can get those on lock, whatever fits into the remaining spaces will benefit greatly from the structure, stability, and order.

text_content: The teacher fills the jar with the largest stuff first, and the other things fall into the cracks, allowing for a greater and tighter fit.Iâ€™m visiting family again. One of the things that stuck out to me this time is how hard it is for me to focus and operate when I donâ€™t have stability, a fact that is made ruthlessly clear to me every time I come here. My mom has gone out of her way to try to accommodate me, going so far as to set up a â€œbed tentâ€ over the futon, to offer some privacy and keep the light out. Iâ€™m grateful, and it does improve the sleeping situation, but it doesnâ€™t fix the sound issues. And it makes the ventilation worse. Iâ€™m not trying to complain, but to illustrate that it took going from having the best sleep Iâ€™ve had in weeks at home to struggling to get comfortable and sleep here, just for me to realize just how much my sleep is impacting my entire life.I had a moment where, sitting at the dining table (which Iâ€™ve all but taken over as my workspace), I looked over at the kitchen and my mind drifted to thinking about life and work. And I realized in that moment that the shape of my thoughts were so constrained by how I was feeling in my body. The fatigue had changed my baseline and made it hard to think or care about anything. Without limited external obligations or engagements hanging on me, I was left to just experience my actual perceptions and conceptions about life, the world, and what I wanted.

text_content: â€œTranscendent harmony and goodness, the kind I can imagine in my heart, are real destinations that can and should be planned, oriented towards, and otherwise engineered, and my involvement in that enterprise is important to me and my life as a whole.â€Whew. How does that one sound? Maybe a little idealistic? Maybe obviously true?The belief that has replaced it is kinda boring and maybe even disjoint. Itâ€™s something like:â€œThe world is a chaotic, living and breathing place. All attempts to regularize, systematize, harmonize, standardize, or otherwise organize it according to some emergent goal will failâ€”see the Hairy Ball Theorem. The true nature of this experience is not one to be captured, perfected, or preserved. Itâ€™s much more akin to a dynamic exploration of atypical experiences. text_content: Either way, the reality Iâ€™m shifting into is one in which my efforts and commitments are less external, less object-oriented, less contingent. I canâ€™t say that â€œsolving problemsâ€ is an autotelic activity. Problems are transient, subjective, and contextual. Sure, you can point to problems that are less transient, less subjective, and less contextual than othersâ€”problems of larger scale or deeper relation to the human experience. And yet, those problems will still contain subject and context that someone from a different experience or culture might be able to point out, even if you and everyone you know and love canâ€™t see it. In such a world, my choices, actions, and commitments become less about full-fledged humanistic endeavors and more like improvisational jazz. The conundrum of my experience as a human being is not a riddle to be solved, but an undulating, expansive, and recursively self-recontextualizing exploration. There is no end, only means, as far as the eye can see.2

text_content: How do I plan or choose for myself in such a regime? From the root. Choices and plans become less about picking destinations and navigating terrain in hope of arrival at some pre-specified end, and more about dynamically exploring the state-space of experience. What does living in this choice feel like? What do I learn about myself and others when pursuing this plan? How do I navigate all of these choices in a way that extinguishes karma (if thatâ€™s even useful, or possible)? These are fascinating questions to ask. At the end of the day, Iâ€™m never as alive as when Iâ€™m exploring the strange and unexpected reality right in front of my faceâ€”whether Iâ€™m doing it with a pen, a keyboard, or a pair of hiking shoes. Can I make sense of it? Maybe not! But I can sure try to make contact with it.Hereâ€™s one last image that explains where Iâ€™m at with all of this. In Everything Everywhere All at Once, Waymond explains to Evelyn how to verse jump: â€œWe developed an algorithm that calculates which statistically improbable action will place you in a universe on the edge of your local cluster, which then slingshots you to the desired universe.â€

text_content: Iâ€™ve been downsizing at my place, lately. What I mean is that Iâ€™m getting rid of things I own. A lot of them. Furniture, gadgets, tools, toys, and so much more. Iâ€™ve acquired so many things over the last 20-odd years. The majority of these things are recent acquisitions, perhaps from the last 5-10 years. Many of the furnishings from my house are from my failed attempt to set it up as an AirBnB property. My thinking at the time was â€œI donâ€™t want to live here full time, but I love to stay here, and itâ€™s nice to have a secure base that doubles as a storage unit.â€ Unfortunately, it wasnâ€™t a lucrative enough property to justify keeping that going. I ran the numbers for the year that I had it going and I was sorely disappointed. I decided to pull the plug on it last year, and following YABU (yet another breakup), I moved back in and settled in, full-time.It was nice, at first. I remember posting about how much I loved it here.A heartfelt post from back in April about how it felt to settle in with myself. It worked. Iâ€™m here and the restlessness has subsided.And it was good. It was helpful. The routine, the stability, the seclusion. These all helped me confront and move through things that I needed to move through. I am grateful.

text_content: And yet... I am ready to leave. I have processed as much as I could stand to processâ€”disappointing jobs, relationships, the last of my old hopes and aspirations. This house has come to physically symbolize the marsh of my malcontent; so many of the things I have accumulated here remind me in some way of those things that I have left behind in all but memento and memory. I have held space for the memories. I am as fine with those now as I could possibly be. Now that I donâ€™t feel the need to run from or duck them, I am ready to truly let them all go. Physically.I am ready to let go of the items I bought to furnish this place, letting the sting and the frustration of the failure of that attempt to live up to the intentions and expectations I had for it, at the same time. Tonight, a woman from Facebook came over to pick through the items. When she bought the daybed that took me months of backlisted waiting to purchase both parts of, for a fraction of what they originally cost, something inside me winced twiceâ€”once for the nostalgia and another for the fiscal loss. And then I was free. And I was, in a small way, grateful that the piece I so loved had found a new home with someone who I imagine will grow to appreciate it, too.The complete living room, before the sales. Defender tries to explain how Open Memetics relates to ORI. Thereâ€™s some back-and-forth about Venn diagrams and prerequisites. Benjamin lands on a pretty clean definition: OMI is â€œa resource for anyone who wants to clean up a specific scopeâ€ of their information environment.

2. Whoâ€™s the User Here? (9:09 - 23:05)

We get into scope questionsâ€”like, is this for everyone, or just for people who already get it? Defender talks about wanting â€œone of eachâ€ (one memetically literate person in every information network). The bar for entry is actually pretty high, which creates tension with the â€œeveryone can participateâ€ framing.

3. The Bug Report Model (23:05 - 40:12)

Defender explains this idea where anyone can come to OMI and basically file a complaint about propaganda or bad information. Even if theyâ€™re wrong about whatâ€™s propaganda, that itself is useful dataâ€”it tells you something about their information environment. Itâ€™s kind of elegant, actually. Benjamin and I push back a bit on whether â€œfind a base stationâ€ is really the right first step versus helping people understand their own epistemology first.

4. Is This Stuff Safe to Publish? (40:12 - 1:00:07)

text_content: Benjamin asks whether open research on manipulation techniques is dangerous. We kick around whether bad actors already know this stuff, whether the cognitive bar to understand it is a natural filter, and what happens if you accidentally give people tools to destabilize things faster than they can adapt. I throw in the point about timingâ€”if you remove a governmentâ€™s ability to run propaganda overnight, that could mean violent revolution, not utopia.5. Pull vs. Push and the Influencer Network (1:00:07 - 1:26:47)Defender talks about wanting to deploy solutions through a network of influencers who opt in to spread good information. Benjamin pushes back on whether â€œpullâ€ (people choosing to adopt ideas because theyâ€™re good) is enough by itself. Thereâ€™s some useful friction here about what OMI actually doesâ€”is it just research, or is it actively shaping culture?6. Whatâ€™s Actually Missing (1:26:47 - end)This is where it gets practical. Benjaminâ€™s like, â€œI donâ€™t feel onboarded, I just had a good conversation.â€ And heâ€™s right. Whatâ€™s missing isnâ€™t ideasâ€”itâ€™s community infrastructure. Names and faces. Someone to say â€œhey, did you do the thing?â€ I push on the accountability piece because Iâ€™ve seen how organizations actually move: somebody has to be waiting on the work. Benjamin reframes it as wanting to know his work matters to specific people, not just to some abstract mission. We land on: maybe just get everyone on a Zoom call and let them talk to each other.

text_content: I want to write, but Iâ€™m not sure what to write on.I have been thinking a LOT, lately. Coming back from SF, I was a bit shocked to land back at my house. Itâ€™s empty and remote. My routine isâ€”for lack of a better wordâ€”dismal and boring. I went from hanging out with Omar every day to hanging out with myself. It was starkly clear that I want out of this place. Iâ€™m working now on making that happen. In my mind, the biggest step to do that is to empty my house of my possessions. They have to go somewhere. Iâ€™m going through the awkward and uncomfortable process of acknowledging â€œI donâ€™t need that,â€ dozens of times a day. Itâ€™s an interesting challenge.Meanwhile, to keep my spirits up, or out of old habit, Iâ€™ve been thinking and thinking. Thinking about â€œmy life,â€ thinking about â€œthe world,â€ and thinking about nearly everything in between. â€œWhat do I want to doâ€ is a question that keeps coming up a lot. If anything, Iâ€™ve been thinking too much. Iâ€™ve run myself in circles, thinking of things that appeal to me, and thinking my way out of them.

text_content: For instance, the Discourse Maps I worked on, as interesting as they are, donâ€™t feel like theyâ€™re actually useful for anything. Like... okay, say you dump some tweets into one. You get a view into the shape of the discourse. Or the nature of the arguments therein. Then what? To what end do we discourse? To what end do we argue? Is improving the quality of discourse on Twitter something I care about? In some ways it feels like trying to desalinate the ocean.These days I see Twitter as a samsara realm, the only meaningful outcome being escape. Why would I be creating tools whose implicit goal is to get people to interact on Twitter more? Itâ€™s like working for the Google Maps team and saying â€œI want to make tools that help people spend more time navigating.â€ What? The point of a map is to get where youâ€™re going. But Twitter is like maps for the lost, who donâ€™t particularly care where theyâ€™re going or why. Sometimes they find each otherâ€”Iâ€™ve made friends on there and I love that. And yet to use it more deeply than that feels more like a coping strategy than a meaningful addition to oneâ€™s life. Maybe itâ€™s just not shaped for my brain.My latest thoughts about how I might move Discourse Maps forward.Of course, my problems with Twitter are not limited to Twitter. I feel this way about a lot of the stuff we all say and do. I say this with full acknowledgement that this is probably a me problem more than a Twitter problem. Imagine a nutritionally starved guy complaining about fast food restaurants, or the chips and soda aisle. Maybe the problem is me?

text_content: One of the biggest things I think about regularly is what matters in life? Like, truly?If you were an alien who understood that humans are intelligent, biological creatures, but you couldnâ€™t understand our language, what would you see?We move, we communicate, we engage with material reality around us in broadly categorical ways. We look, think, speak, feel, move, and breathe. For example, we all spend hours a day staring at screens. If you understood that we were conscious and doing some kind of internal processing as we move through the world, it would probably become clear that these screens hold some kind of relevance to that processing. You might intuit that the screens can store and retrieve symbolic information that we somehow link to our internal processing.

text_content: Another thing we do a lot is meet and speak. Sometimes these periods of speaking are short, and even paired with the exchange of material (goods, money). Other times, these periods are long. You might observe that humans have a certain â€œvibeâ€â€”the way they move and speak occupies largely coherent states, low energy, high energy, quick, and slow. From this, you might intuit that humansâ€™ interactions with each other and their symbolic screens can be predicted by the vibes; the screens seem to be encoding those, too. Interactions seem to follow chemical rulesâ€”vibes are part, and the information content (mystery that it is) must be part, too, since the vibes alone donâ€™t perfectly predict the outcomes.

text_content: After observing these curious creatures for some time, you might conclude that their motivation and control mechanisms are quite simple. You might develop a classification system that you can generally lump different humans into. Although the content of their screens and the interactions they have may be completely different between each human in a cluster, what vibes they seem to return to and the patterns of movement they follow might seem to follow predictable forms. And it may begin to dawn on you that the human being might actually be overarchingly guided by a desire to exist in a specific dynamic state space, a particular form of dynamic homeostatic equilibrium with its environment, moving between poles and charges in a predictable, definable way. You might conclude, noticing this, that the specific content in the humanâ€™s experience doesnâ€™t matter as much as the dynamic structure it creates.

text_content: And then you might wonder, if humans are conceptually so simple, why do they seem to slip out of these equilibria so frequently? I mean, accidents and unexpected things happenâ€”theyâ€™re part of your experience as an alien, too; we live in the same shared reality, after all. But... these humans also seem to make choices that actually move them away from their baselines! Itâ€™s almost as ifâ€”and surely you know this is crazy, because if you can see it, how can they notâ€”they donâ€™t know their own energetic baselines! But how could that be? Theyâ€™re so obvious! If you, disconnected from them as you are, could see it, of course they must be able to see it, too! They are, after all, experiencing them firsthand. It would take some incredible impairment in that supposed â€œinner experienceâ€ we surmised they have, or some even more incredible and unfortunate accidental misdirection for them to miss something so glaringly obvious... no?

text_content: And yet, as a human, I am here to tell you, we are indeed missing it. We humans live in an object-level trance, not seeing the congruences across our own behaviors and needs, dreaming that the differences we see are differences in kind and not quality. Itâ€™s a dream of perceptual complexity. â€œWeâ€™re absolutely not simple creatures,â€ we assert, with every quixotic contortion of our beings, insisting that the harmony and balance we seek is always one step off, always necessitating more... more thinking, more reasoning, more changing, more minute arranging of the quirkiest details of our experience, not realizing that the way we do this reasoning, changing, and arranging is itself a pale simulacrum of the ideal unsimulated expressions of our innate dynamism.

text_content: Are you still following me, alien friend? Iâ€™m saying that human beings have an internal experience, a sense of an agent, and also a sense of the entire reality that agent engages in, and this agent directs their behavior to try to arrange the reality into structures and forms that they prefer. Moreoverâ€”and this is the silliest partâ€”those directions, by the agent, are thrown off by the humanâ€™s own underlying dynamism. When the instructions of the agent contradict the humanâ€™s own underlying desire for authentic self-expressionâ€”whether the contradiction is minor, such as saying something untrue or omitting something true, or if the contradiction is major, such as doing work and staring at screens that clash with the humanâ€™s vibeâ€”the underlying dynamism will create a chaotic cacophony deep in the human, which inevitably must leak out. It always does. And we humans seem to be perpetually confused by this. Itâ€™s as if the agent doesnâ€™t have the ability to look at what the human is doing and reconcile that something is missing. The agent seems to dream up one single complicated state of perfection after another, rather than seeing the truth: humans are simple creatures who desire nothing more than to exist in a wave of patterns of dynamic homeostasis with their environment, mediated by their own â€œthoughtsâ€ and â€œcommunicationâ€ with others.The humans who know this, either explicitly, or intuitively, are the happiest, liveliest, and most dynamic of them all.

Are you still following me, alien friend? Iâ€™m saying that human beings have an internal experience, a sense of an agent, and also a sense of the entire reality that agent engages in, and this agent directs their behavior to try to arrange the reality into structures and forms that they prefer. Moreoverâ€”and this is the silliest partâ€”those directions, by the agent, are thrown off by the humanâ€™s own underlying dynamism. When the instructions of the agent contradict the humanâ€™s own underlying desire for authentic self-expressionâ€”whether the contradiction is minor, such as saying something untrue or omitting something true, or if the contradiction is major, such as doing work and staring at screens that clash with the humanâ€™s vibeâ€”the underlying dynamism will create a chaotic cacophony deep in the human, which inevitably must leak out. It always does. And we humans seem to be perpetually confused by this. Itâ€™s as if the agent doesnâ€™t have the ability to look at what the human is doing and reconcile that something is missing. The agent seems to dream up one single complicated state of perfection after another, rather than seeing the truth: humans are simple creatures who desire nothing more than to exist in a wave of patterns of dynamic homeostasis with their environment, mediated by their own â€œthoughtsâ€ and â€œcommunicationâ€ with others.

The humans who know this, either explicitly, or intuitively, are the happiest, liveliest, and most dynamic of them all.

text_content: Defender and I gave this talk at the 2025 Love Symposium in SF about our project from the memetics lab at ORI. We call it â€œAnatomy of an Internet Argument,â€ though  I enjoy the alternate title: â€œHow to Propagate Love in a War Zoneâ€ (the hostile internet being the war zone).Check out the slides, here.The title slide for the talk, by yours truly and his favorite bird friend.The whole thing started because Defender kept getting into these nasty Twitter exchanges that would ruin his day. Heâ€™s says heâ€™s got thin skin, and getting dunked on by random internet strangers is genuinely painful. Instead of just blocking everyone or leaving Twitter, though, he developed a technique for turning hostile exchanges into productive conversations that change minds and often make friends.If you are trying to hold good in your heart, you may find that the internet makes this really hard. This oneâ€™s for you.The key is to treat it like a game where you can always winâ€”you just have to redefine the win condition. Bronze is understanding what the other person is actually saying. Silver is getting them to understand you. Gold is when you actually change someoneâ€™s mind. The trick is that bronze is entirely in your control. You can always seek to understand someone, even if theyâ€™re being a total jerk.The AoIA prizes. Always go for bronze first!
html_content:
Defender and I gave this talk at the 2025 Love Symposium in SF about our project from the memetics lab at ORI. We call it â€œAnatomy of an Internet Argument,â€ though I enjoy the alternate title: â€œHow to Propagate Love in a War Zoneâ€ (the hostile internet being the war zone).

Check out the slides, here.

The whole thing started because Defender kept getting into these nasty Twitter exchanges that would ruin his day. Heâ€™s says heâ€™s got thin skin, and getting dunked on by random internet strangers is genuinely painful. Instead of just blocking everyone or leaving Twitter, though, he developed a technique for turning hostile exchanges into productive conversations that change minds and often make friends.

The key is to treat it like a game where you can always winâ€”you just have to redefine the win condition. Bronze is understanding what the other person is actually saying. Silver is getting them to understand you. Gold is when you actually change someoneâ€™s mind. The trick is that bronze is entirely in your control. You can always seek to understand someone, even if theyâ€™re being a total jerk.

text_content: We showed a bunch of examples where Defender would respond to hostility with genuine curiosity and good faith, and people would completely turn around. Like this guy who came in hot, calling something Defender loved â€œa shitload to brainwash the masses,â€ and Defender responded by asking to read the guyâ€™s vision of utopia. The hostile guy immediately flipped to â€œwow, thatâ€™s the best possible thing to have said.â€He came in hot, but Defender turned him around in one cool move.I also showed some visualization tools I built that piggy back off of @HumanCompressedâ€™s PostScope, which map out these conversations in semantic space. You can literally watch Defender walking people from the hostile, closed-minded corner of the graph over to the open, collaborative quadrant. Itâ€™s like watching someone land a crashing plane.Some of the tools, which can be found on my Twitter, hosted versions coming soon (hopefully). Clockwise from top left: conversation path mapper, tweet categories, tweet compass, logical argument graphs.The protocol works because itâ€™s asymmetric. You donâ€™t need the other person to follow any rules. You just need to genuinely assume theyâ€™re arguing in good faith, show them you understand them (and get confirmationâ€”the â€œhandshakeâ€), and remember that facts donâ€™t actually change minds. The intuitive, emotional brain leads; the rational brain just rationalizes after the fact.The rules of the AoIA game are actually quite simple.

We showed a bunch of examples where Defender would respond to hostility with genuine curiosity and good faith, and people would completely turn around. Like this guy who came in hot, calling something Defender loved â€œa shitload to brainwash the masses,â€ and Defender responded by asking to read the guyâ€™s vision of utopia. The hostile guy immediately flipped to â€œwow, thatâ€™s the best possible thing to have said.â€

I also showed some visualization tools I built that piggy back off of @HumanCompressedâ€™s PostScope, which map out these conversations in semantic space. You can literally watch Defender walking people from the hostile, closed-minded corner of the graph over to the open, collaborative quadrant. Itâ€™s like watching someone land a crashing plane.

The protocol works because itâ€™s asymmetric. You donâ€™t need the other person to follow any rules. You just need to genuinely assume theyâ€™re arguing in good faith, show them you understand them (and get confirmationâ€”the â€œhandshakeâ€), and remember that facts donâ€™t actually change minds. The intuitive, emotional brain leads; the rational brain just rationalizes after the fact.

text_content: The most counterintuitive part is that you have to actually love the person first to understand themâ€”â€œlove is epistemologically necessaryâ€ as Lulie put it. If you think someoneâ€™s an idiot, you literally canâ€™t model why a reasonable person would say what theyâ€™re saying. You have to start from â€œthis person is the hero of their own storyâ€ and work backwards.The operating principles may seem like a stretch, but they really do work. If you can train yourself to operate from this basis, you can change minds just like Defender.We ended by showing how this scales. When one person uses these techniques successfully, observers are blown away. They post things like â€œthis civil Twitter exchange is a true Christmas miracle.â€ And then those people try it themselves. It spreads.Looks like Santa came early this year.The ultimate goal isnâ€™t to win arguments; itâ€™s to extract whatever truth the other person has, even if theyâ€™re being hostile about sharing it. Sometimes that angry anime avatar actually knows something you donâ€™t. And even if they donâ€™t, the 14-year-old reading the thread might learn something from watching you engage constructively.These techniques work even in hostile environments, although they take some precision and skill to deploy. At the end of the day, itâ€™s up to you to decide when to argue, and when to walk.
html_content:
The most counterintuitive part is that you have to actually love the person first to understand themâ€”â€œlove is epistemologically necessaryâ€ as Lulie put it. If you think someoneâ€™s an idiot, you literally canâ€™t model why a reasonable person would say what theyâ€™re saying. You have to start from â€œthis person is the hero of their own storyâ€ and work backwards.

We ended by showing how this scales. When one person uses these techniques successfully, observers are blown away. They post things like â€œthis civil Twitter exchange is a true Christmas miracle.â€ And then those people try it themselves. It spreads.

The ultimate goal isnâ€™t to win arguments; itâ€™s to extract whatever truth the other person has, even if theyâ€™re being hostile about sharing it. Sometimes that angry anime avatar actually knows something you donâ€™t. And even if they donâ€™t, the 14-year-old reading the thread might learn something from watching you engage constructively.

html_content:
Chapters

Introduction [00:00]

Defender introduces himself and the project â€œAnatomy of an Internet Argument,â€ alternatively titled â€œHow to Propagate Love in a War Zoneâ€ (the hostile internet)

The triggering example [00:49]

Defender shows a real Twitter exchange where someone attacks something he loves, calling it â€œbrainwash for the masses,â€ and reveals his surprising response that completely flipped the interaction

The secret: genuine good faith [02:03]

Breaking down why assuming genuine good faith (not faking it) changes everything; imagining the hostile account might be a secret brilliant personâ€™s alt

Theater that restores faith [03:54]

Examples of observers being shocked by civil exchanges (â€œa true Christmas miracleâ€), showing how rare and powerful these interactions appear to others

Personal stakes [04:50]

Defender explains his thin skin and vulnerability. Without these techniques, he couldnâ€™t write on the internet despite having 10,000 followers

The protocol design [05:51]

Explaining this as an asymmetric social protocol that works even when youâ€™re the only one following it, unlike LessWrongâ€™s protocols that require buy-in

The core axioms [08:58]

The beliefs you need to hold (even just as a game):

  • Everyone argues in good faith

  • Everyone is rational and will change beliefs given reasons

  • You must show them you understand, not just understand

  • No one changes their mind if they feel like theyâ€™ll lose

Why facts donâ€™t change minds [11:40]

The intuitive mind leads and the rational mind follows. Facts are useless without emotional buy-in

Love is epistemologically necessary [12:23]

The four steps [14:00]

  1. Understanding the other person (Bronze medals are always achievable)

  2. Getting them to understand you (Silver)

text_content: I did another Radical Honesty retreat.Me, sharing my lifeâ€™s story with the group. It was a challenge to compress it into 30 minutes, but it was effective; the telling brought with it a lot of the unresolved feelings and conditionings that still remain. 10/10, would tell again.The first one I did was in August, with Heidi Priebe. It was a lot! Good things, entirely, but a lot of work and a lot of emotions and reflections and integration. I canâ€™t overstate the value of safe containers, in which we can steadily grow in trust until it feels safe enough to really let ourselves feel and show our deeper emotions. Thatâ€¦ is huge.I truly believe that the safety and security of the [therapeutic/work/relationship] container is the most important factor for growth, success, and thriving.This one was in Costa Rica. That brought with it its own adjustments and reflections. Being in another country, driving around and exploring is a favorite pastime of mine, and this was a welcome adventure. I struggled with some depression and fear I was carrying which made the first half (pre-retreat) of the trip feel a bit underwhelming (I spent most of the time indoors, writing, reflecting, and collaborating with friends back home).

text_content: Fast forward to the retreat. A lot of the content was similar. We work through partner exercises, process emotions and narratives in the presence of the whole group, and do hotseat work to dive deeper into longer-standing challenges that have plagued us in various ways throughout our lives.For me, the experience of this one was a subtler version of what happened last time. As with before, I would encounter and process triggers while in the large groupâ€”things like:My feelings around needing to be capable or effective (an identity differentiation I picked up when I was a child), which I stumbled on when my 1:1 partner was practicing asking for more money from his clients;My self-alienation in both my body image and my work, a subtle but potent form of disassociation that I learned to simultaneously compel myself to act (tyrannical, top-down) and to defend myself from othersâ€™ judgements about my state and progress, or lack thereof, which appeared to be somehow connected to some early maternal experience around learning and self-image;My long-stored, latent frustration/desperation that â€œsomething has to be done, but I have nothing I can doâ€ which manifests as impotent rage that wants to express and be destructive, but melts into sadness and tenderness when the opportunity to destroy is presented (such as when one of the facilitators, Tony, handed me a guitar).
html_content:
Fast forward to the retreat. A lot of the content was similar. We work through partner exercises, process emotions and narratives in the presence of the whole group, and do hotseat work to dive deeper into longer-standing challenges that have plagued us in various ways throughout our lives.

For me, the experience of this one was a subtler version of what happened last time. As with before, I would encounter and process triggers while in the large groupâ€”things like:

  1. My feelings around needing to be capable or effective (an identity differentiation I picked up when I was a child), which I stumbled on when my 1:1 partner was practicing asking for more money from his clients;

  2. My self-alienation in both my body image and my work, a subtle but potent form of disassociation that I learned to simultaneously compel myself to act (tyrannical, top-down) and to defend myself from othersâ€™ judgements about my state and progress, or lack thereof, which appeared to be somehow connected to some early maternal experience around learning and self-image;

  3. My long-stored, latent frustration/desperation that â€œsomething has to be done, but I have nothing I can doâ€ which manifests as impotent rage that wants to express and be destructive, but melts into sadness and tenderness when the opportunity to destroy is presented (such as when one of the facilitators, Tony, handed me a guitar).

text_content: Whereas before I felt overwhelmed by some of these movements; whereas there was a fear about their resolution, about what I needed to do in response to the feelings and situations; whereas there was a â€œdestinationâ€ that I needed to navigate to by â€œlearningâ€ how to beâ€¦ this time, it came down to completely inhabiting the experience, sometimes with group support, sometimes silently and momentarily, and letting my internal resistance to being in it gently dissolve. In each case, there was a special moment in which the stress and urgency and disassociation of the experience turned over into â€œI can be in this, and actually being in it with nothing to do or be or change is quite lovely.â€ I still remember sitting in the simultaneous feelings of anger and care for my mother, realizing there was nothing I could do to resolve it, and reconsolidating that memory under the understanding that, if I were to find myself in that experience again, as that 11 year old, in a standoff with my motherâ€™s diehard intent to teach me my timestables, I would simply go to my room and sit with those feelings of frustration, sadness, impotence, and disconnection. My life would have played out so differently if someone had taught me to do that right then and there. Alas, with this gold nugget in my pocket, I may yet be a potent teacher for others.

text_content: So now we arrive at the present. Iâ€™m sitting in a cafe, with my friend, DefenderOfBasic, across the room, charging his laptop and watching an ORI member livestream some of his work.And here we observe the humble memetics avian, in his natural habitat, perched at a coffee shop, feasting on high-signal information streams.And Iâ€™m here, processing my feelings after a day and a night of some rather interesting and intense experiences. Weâ€™ve hung out with some fellow folks from Twitter, some authors and interesting folks at Lighthaven, and a handful of other folks (you know who you are). And in the midst of these experiences, Iâ€™ve been mildly focused, in the background, on some of the nuances of my experience. I donâ€™t want to go into too much detail, because itâ€™s personal and involves others who deserve discretion and privacy, but I will describe how the experience of facing and feeling these things has changed, in my experience.Yesterday, I found myself in a situation with someone else which was quite, uh, experientially complicated (i.e., there was a lot of emotional and cognitive content, and some of my conditioning and attachment system stuff was quite online). In the midst of this experience, I was holding space with this person and they were holding space with me, I got to experience the feelings and triggers that were coming up, again without having to do anything about them. That was excellent. Lovely. Healing. Aaaaandâ€¦ something else showed up, too.

text_content: I canâ€™t tell if it was oxytocin and dopamine overdrive just shifting my consciousness, or if all the work Iâ€™ve been doing had loosened my habitual grip on reality, butâ€¦ I sat there staring at what was before me, letting my attention drift over the surroundings, my conceptions of the world around me, and the projections I was holding about the future, and I found them all to beâ€¦ missing those essential handles that I had gripped so tightly, before. Was this disassociation? Hard to tell. What I would like to believe is that the structures of mind that grew long ago, aimed at securing â€œmyâ€ place and path in reality, have continued to subside a bit, to the point that thereâ€™s noticeably something missing. Itâ€™s subtle, but I can see a clearing where the web of thoughts that held together a coherent sense of a first-person navigating and holding back this reality used to be.Is this desirable? I canâ€™t tell! I mean, I wanted this. I wanted to loosen my grip. I wanted to start to separate my seeing from my movement, and to start to play with the (apparent) bounds and edges of my experience, letting things unfold and flow before me, to shift into a more participatory mode of being. Reality is not some dumb territory I need to navigate, compel, and conquer, but a living, breathing thing that is indeed inseparable from whatever I take myself to be, even if that â€taking myself to beâ€ feels, like a separable experience. Itâ€™s a trick on the mind, and one I intent to continue unlearning.

text_content: We started with Defender showing off Evalâ€™s notebook setup and talking about wanting to actualize an essay idea collaboratively. This led us into yet another sprawling conversation about what ORI actually is and how to make it sustainable.The big revelation for me came when Defender explained how ORI works as a funding pipeline: companies like Analog want to fund projects that generate either breakthroughs or â€œsplashâ€ (hype that attracts more resources). Iâ€™d always been skeptical of hype, but I suddenly realized itâ€™s not inherently badâ€”itâ€™s about tilling the soil, preparing the market to meet you when youâ€™re ready. The problem is mistaking hype for the actual finished work.We got into the economics of it all: how do you know if youâ€™re creating real value versus just moving money around in circles? How is this different from a Ponzi scheme? The answer is that you need people with good discernment to look at the whole system and evaluate whether projects are actually creating new purpose, not just GDP. Thatâ€™s what ORI doesâ€”itâ€™s a discernment engine, or as Defender put it, â€œan incubator / church.â€The hardest part is that Defender attracts people who donâ€™t fit anywhere else and gives them hope, but doesnâ€™t have enough resources to help everyone. That gap between aspiration and execution is painful. We talked about how projects need owners, how research needs PMs, and how you have to pick winners even when you believe everyoneâ€™s a winner.
html_content:
We started with Defender showing off Evalâ€™s notebook setup and talking about wanting to actualize an essay idea collaboratively. This led us into yet another sprawling conversation about what ORI actually is and how to make it sustainable.

The big revelation for me came when Defender explained how ORI works as a funding pipeline: companies like Analog want to fund projects that generate either breakthroughs or â€œsplashâ€ (hype that attracts more resources). Iâ€™d always been skeptical of hype, but I suddenly realized itâ€™s not inherently badâ€”itâ€™s about tilling the soil, preparing the market to meet you when youâ€™re ready. The problem is mistaking hype for the actual finished work.

We got into the economics of it all: how do you know if youâ€™re creating real value versus just moving money around in circles? How is this different from a Ponzi scheme? The answer is that you need people with good discernment to look at the whole system and evaluate whether projects are actually creating new purpose, not just GDP. Thatâ€™s what ORI doesâ€”itâ€™s a discernment engine, or as Defender put it, â€œan incubator / church.â€

The hardest part is that Defender attracts people who donâ€™t fit anywhere else and gives them hope, but doesnâ€™t have enough resources to help everyone. That gap between aspiration and execution is painful. We talked about how projects need owners, how research needs PMs, and how you have to pick winners even when you believe everyoneâ€™s a winner.

[52:04] Small scale society and the purpose economy

Thought experiment about a 100-person society where someone invents a machine that frees up labor. What do people do with that freed time? They create new purposes (like haircuts). The economy grows by creating and fulfilling purpose, not just by GDP.

Type 1: fun in the moment. Type 2: fun after the fact (building something meaningful). Type 3: sacrifice. Weâ€™re really talking about how people allocate attention in ways that feel internally coherent. The alignment problem is about helping people who lack purpose either create it or find unfulfilled purpose in society.

[1:01:22] ORI as church and the tldraw homepage idea

Defender wants the ORI homepage to be a live whiteboard that shows the current state of everything. Your workspace should be your documentationâ€”just make it public and surface the work instead of documenting separately.

To speak someoneâ€™s language well enough to influence them, you have to actually think like them. You canâ€™t hate someone and understand themâ€”hate is a cognitive handicap, love is a cognitive nootropic. Weâ€™re doing open experiments in understanding people and normalizing that approach.

People are using Twitter to:

To what end? Well, we communicate with others in a clumsy, two-way modality, and we get ideas, validation, and perspectival mirroring back. text_content: Figure out whatâ€™s at stake and whatâ€™s really thereAlign their own thoughts and positions relative to whatâ€™s around themStay focused and on track; filter out noise, filter in signal, continuously, in coherence with what theyâ€™re doingThese systems and tools are akin to reading glasses, metronomes, and air conditioners. The aim of these tools is to reduce epistemic noise, narrow semantic drift, standardize ontological connections. The idea is that, without tools and technology to help us, we are liable and likely to run amok in our thinking and communicating. But with the intellectual equivalent of lane keep assist and emergency collision avoidance, we can have a smoother, safer, and more rewarding time.The idea is that we should ask ourselves, implicitly and explicitly, â€œWhat am I getting out of this? Where is this going? How am I engaging with this? Why do I care?â€Every interaction, every scroll, and every tap can be an opportunity to nudge ourselves closer to what we value and what we desire for ourselves. Each bit might take us closer to connection and communion with ourselves, and as a pleasant byproduct, with each other.
html_content:
1. Figure out whatâ€™s at stake and whatâ€™s really there

  2. Align their own thoughts and positions relative to whatâ€™s around them

  3. Stay focused and on track; filter out noise, filter in signal, continuously, in coherence with what theyâ€™re doing

These systems and tools are akin to reading glasses, metronomes, and air conditioners. The aim of these tools is to reduce epistemic noise, narrow semantic drift, standardize ontological connections. The idea is that, without tools and technology to help us, we are liable and likely to run amok in our thinking and communicating. But with the intellectual equivalent of lane keep assist and emergency collision avoidance, we can have a smoother, safer, and more rewarding time.

The idea is that we should ask ourselves, implicitly and explicitly, â€œWhat am I getting out of this? Where is this going? How am I engaging with this? Why do I care?â€

Every interaction, every scroll, and every tap can be an opportunity to nudge ourselves closer to what we value and what we desire for ourselves. Each bit might take us closer to connection and communion with ourselves, and as a pleasant byproduct, with each other.

text_content: Caught up with Defender for our Monday session where heâ€™s starting something newâ€”weekly planning rhythms and moving from day-long sprints to week-long projects. Itâ€™s a phase change, as I called it. We ended up going deep on his latest Twitter experiment: using it as a classroom to analyze Spotifyâ€™s sneaky â€œnot-quite-adsâ€ with his audience.The conversation evolved into something much bigger: how do we actually understand people we disagree with? Defenderâ€™s been developing this framework called â€œThe Anatomy of an Argument,â€ built on a powerful insight: you literally cannot understand someoneâ€™s position if you hold them in contempt. Itâ€™s not just morally wrong; itâ€™s epistemologically impossible. Contempt creates a cognitive handicap.We explored this paradox: if you solve psychological safety in arguments, you donâ€™t need to â€œwinâ€ anymore. But if you actually want to win, creating that safety is the necessary first step. It reminds me of those movie scenes where the race winner stands alone while the â€œloserâ€ is surrounded by friendsâ€¦ what does winning really mean?Weâ€™re preparing to present some of these ideas at the Love Symposium in San Francisco, focusing on how love (or at least believing others are good and reasonable) is epistemologically necessary for truth-seeking. Plus discussions on binary thinking, superposition of ideas, and why Defenderâ€™s turning everything into content (then pulling back from that impulse).

Caught up with Defender for our Monday session where heâ€™s starting something newâ€”weekly planning rhythms and moving from day-long sprints to week-long projects. Itâ€™s a phase change, as I called it. We ended up going deep on his latest Twitter experiment: using it as a classroom to analyze Spotifyâ€™s sneaky â€œnot-quite-adsâ€ with his audience.

The conversation evolved into something much bigger: how do we actually understand people we disagree with? Defenderâ€™s been developing this framework called â€œThe Anatomy of an Argument,â€ built on a powerful insight: you literally cannot understand someoneâ€™s position if you hold them in contempt. Itâ€™s not just morally wrong; itâ€™s epistemologically impossible. Contempt creates a cognitive handicap.

We explored this paradox: if you solve psychological safety in arguments, you donâ€™t need to â€œwinâ€ anymore. But if you actually want to win, creating that safety is the necessary first step. It reminds me of those movie scenes where the race winner stands alone while the â€œloserâ€ is surrounded by friendsâ€¦ what does winning really mean?

Weâ€™re preparing to present some of these ideas at the Love Symposium in San Francisco, focusing on how love (or at least believing others are good and reasonable) is epistemologically necessary for truth-seeking. Plus discussions on binary thinking, superposition of ideas, and why Defenderâ€™s turning everything into content (then pulling back from that impulse).

text_content: It is hard to change.Change is inherent, inevitable, inescapable... it is moment to moment; it is every damn day. And yet, something about who or what we are is wired to writhe and struggle against that. Or to bend and bow, curling up to avoid the currents and float in a tide pool for as long as we possibly can.Who among us doesnâ€™t live like this? Even those most active and flourishing, have they not also fashioned for themselves a lane of their own, in which they can drill down into the same behaviors and patterns that they so particularly enjoy?
html_content:
It is hard to change.

Change is inherent, inevitable, inescapable... it is moment to moment; it is every damn day. And yet, something about who or what we are is wired to writhe and struggle against that. Or to bend and bow, curling up to avoid the currents and float in a tide pool for as long as we possibly can.

Who among us doesnâ€™t live like this? Even those most active and flourishing, have they not also fashioned for themselves a lane of their own, in which they can drill down into the same behaviors and patterns that they so particularly enjoy?

text_content: When there came a clearing, though, it became clear to me that there is so much more to put down. The only way I can describe it is a compassionate kill. Thereâ€™s no grace in death of any kind, except the grace that we the living bring to it. In a case like this, where itâ€™s not my body dying, but some part of my mind, I owe myself that same grace. I owe it to myself to approach this threshold with love, long-suffering, and gratitude.My capacity for tremendous feelings keeps increasing. I surely didnâ€™t ask for this, but every time these waves of profound dissolution rise up to wash over me, they feel even deeper, darker, and more powerful than ever before. Words fail me here. This feeling is such a poignant, ancient grief, a dread that surpasses form. Nothing I can say or see matters to this feeling.And yet, I know what I must doâ€”gently and gracefully put down all of the parts of me that are crying for the relief of dissolution. I will hold watch as they pass, pained as it may make me.

Itâ€™s like early access in video gamesâ€”people literally paying to help build the thing. We explore how this could work with a dedicated Substack, Discord, or even a custom site. text_content: A critical pivot point: should you focus on the book or the consulting? I argue for starting with the book because you know you can deliver it, thereâ€™s a clear market, and it builds your authority. Consulting requires more discoveryâ€”you need to talk to people, understand their problems, and iterate. The book is lower risk and can actually feed into the consulting later.[00:49:14] The Status Hierarchy QuizWe get into a fascinating side-discussion about status calibration and the idea of a quiz that measures where people sit in various status hierarchies. The point I make is that status isnâ€™t one-dimensionalâ€”there are nested games (mainstream, rationalist, post-rationalist, ORI and so many more) and people participate in different ones. Some people idolize you, others think youâ€™re an idiot, and whatâ€™s missing is accurate calibration. The quiz idea is partly tongue-in-cheek but also serious, and the kicker is that status isnâ€™t actually zero-sum because you can just create new games.A loose diagram (left) showing how different â€œstatus realmsâ€ might border and overlap each other, and different â€œstatus measuresâ€ might be shared across different realms and people. Depending on which realms you belong to, a dimensionality reduction over the people you know might yield a very different hierarchy (right).[00:52:03] The Love Symposium Talk

Defender and I will be there![01:12:06] The Infinite Sums AnalogyI share this mind-bending insight from a math video: you can take an infinite series that sums to zero and rearrange the same terms to make it sum to two (or any number). This becomes a perfect metaphor for status gamesâ€”depending on how you structure the game, you can get arbitrary amounts of total status. Itâ€™s not zero-sum if you can reorganize the system. We talk about free energy in human beings and how new status games (like the rationalists created) tap into people who werenâ€™t being rewarded by the mainstream game. Theyâ€™re not stealing from the old game, theyâ€™re activating otherwise dormant energy at the bottom. The key is finding lower-energy orbitals for people to occupyâ€”more efficient social structures that reduce wasted effort.This video illustrates that infinite series can be reconfigured to sum to different finite numbers. One can imagine a similar effect taking place across status gamesâ€”different ways of overlaying and combining status across realms may result in more efficient social organization (e.g., more diverse competition across games/realms, and fewer contested status games).

text_content: [01:16:24] The Steph Curry Tension AnalogyBuilding on the infinite sums idea, I bring up this video of Steph Curry that perfectly illustrates the principle: watch how loose and relaxed he is until the exact moment he needs to be tense. If you can enable people to be lower energy at baseline, they have more free energy available when they actually need it. This connects to the whole status game discussionâ€”if we create nested status games that let people be lower energy (not constantly fighting for position in a system that doesnâ€™t reward them), we can harvest that energy for productive things. Itâ€™s about hollowing out inefficient structures (like Hollywood is already doing to itself) by creating more flexible, compliant systems where people can move around with less friction.Guy shared a Steph Curry video in which he goes from totally loose to immediately tenseâ€”as the moment and the ladyâ€™s safety demanded itâ€”right back to relaxed and lose again.[01:18:34] Accountability and Public CommitmentsWe talk about the value of making public commitmentsâ€”not just to create pressure, but to create open-source learning opportunities. The ORI cohort model provides a structure for this: you announce what youâ€™re working on, check in regularly, and learn from your decisions whether they work out or not. Itâ€™s not about blame, itâ€™s about being honest and self-reflective, and extracting lessons from everything we plan and do.Diagram illustrating the nature of our projections and predictions about what we want and what weâ€™ll do, and the different way things tend to play out.

text_content: Yes, there are fits and starts. Thereâ€™s always some adjustments to make as two people learn the movements and the steps that each other will take. And yet, that too can happen startlingly fast. Again, willingness is impossible to fake, and apparently impossible to ignore.The strange thing Iâ€™m still reeling from, looking now at the pieces of my heart which seem to be trailing along behind me like the clanking of cans behind a car gleefully rushing away from the chapel, except the soft pangs of my heart quietly patter along the asphalt as I begrudgingly drag myself down the road, rushing nowhere in particular... the thing Iâ€™m still reeling from is that the whirlpool of this experience took me, held me, and gently cast me out, to float upon the ripples of my dilute despair.Iâ€™m hurt, and Iâ€™m grateful.

text_content: How could I not be? So much was so gently wrung from within me, and as the slurry of fury and smeared fears dribbled forth, I was awake, aware, and allowed to be with it. I wasnâ€™t called or urged or pressured to fix or forsake myself, and that Grace allowed me to find myself some grace of my own, which I clutch inside me now, now that Iâ€™m alone and have nothing but an ache and some gratitude to spare.I suggest, for those of you who donâ€™t know what Iâ€™m saying, that you bear your open heart gently, and let the one who calls it forth speak directly to you for as long as She or He might do so. Youâ€™ll be surprised what the Words of the Heart have to say. Though they may sound senselessly upon your ears, your heart itself already knows what it wants to do.It needs only one Word or two.
html_content:
How could I not be? So much was so gently wrung from within me, and as the slurry of fury and smeared fears dribbled forth, I was awake, aware, and allowed to be with it. I wasnâ€™t called or urged or pressured to fix or forsake myself, and that Grace allowed me to find myself some grace of my own, which I clutch inside me now, now that Iâ€™m alone and have nothing but an ache and some gratitude to spare.

I suggest, for those of you who donâ€™t know what Iâ€™m saying, that you bear your open heart gently, and let the one who calls it forth speak directly to you for as long as She or He might do so. Youâ€™ll be surprised what the Words of the Heart have to say. Though they may sound senselessly upon your ears, your heart itself already knows what it wants to do.

It needs only one Word or two.

text_content: Once again, your two favorite friends return to think out loud, this time about paradigm shifts, identity, and what it means to find diamonds in the rough without colonizing them.We also explore the tension between rational and intuitive modes of thinking, why mystics and scientists need each other (but canâ€™t always work together), and how cultures preserve themselves while still managing to cooperate. We dive into observer theory, entropy, time as an emergent property, and why Brett Victor was right about killing math (and maybe books too).  Also: Claude made an interactive entropy visualization mid-conversation and it completely derailed us in the best way.

I will explain below.4D diagram depicting the relationships between vision, control, purpose, and impact as they concern goods and services exchanged on the open market. text_content: The irony with all of these philosophical questions is that the answers will always be subjective. They all seem to come back to a shared, simplistic basis: what you believe is what you get. If you believe that something is important, your reasoning will derive from there.At perhaps the lowest level, weâ€™re all bought into one shared core belief: it is better to survive than not. Some intrinsic value of survival pervades everything we do. This makes sense, of course. If we didnâ€™t have that belief (Iâ€™d call it a biological imperative that can be contextualized as a belief), weâ€™d probably sooner die than struggle. These words you are reading are predicated on your survival and mine. Why would I write them if not to that end? This belief drives everything elseâ€”if Iâ€™m driven to survive, that has to be good, right? It has to be worth it, right?In the course of seeking a stable structure of belief that resonates top to bottom and back again, Iâ€™ve returned so many times to the core experience of being alive. What is good for the goose must be good for the gander. If our innate drive to survive suggests that life is supposed to be good, then we should be able to find that goodness quite readily. How plentiful is it? Where does it come from? How do we sustain it?

These words you are reading are predicated on your survival and mine. Why would I write them if not to that end? This belief drives everything elseâ€”if Iâ€™m driven to survive, that has to be good, right? It has to be worth it, right?

In the course of seeking a stable structure of belief that resonates top to bottom and back again, Iâ€™ve returned so many times to the core experience of being alive. How plentiful is it? Where does it come from? How do we sustain it?

text_content: Everyone gets to contend with and wrestle with this set of questions for themselves. Some of us live happily on the surfaceâ€”do good, reap good, and thatâ€™s good. I want a good job, a good family, and a good life. Such a life is filled with many activities that, in their totality, reflect a coherent picture of a good life. Unfortunately, the path to that end often leads to corner cutting. Many of us who pursue it end up compromising significantly to preserve the integrity of the vision. Sometimes, there are enough corners to cut that we donâ€™t run out before we die. For some of us, we run out of cuttable corners far too quickly.When the allure of such a fixation fades too rapidly, like a flame snuffed out before it can take, we must look elsewhere. Many turn to obsession. This can take many forms. I was obsessed with love. Others are obsessed with success. There are many objects of obsession available for the hungry heart. Unfortunately, obsession for me has also worn itself down. I canâ€™t see myself through. The game loopâ€™s waned.

text_content: There is hope, though. There is one thing that sustains me, which I manage to return to again and againâ€”the joy of sensation. I have written about this before. From where I sit, this subtle joy is a universal good, ever present and readily available. Itâ€™s context independent and scale free. If I can breathe, I can access it. Unfortunately, my breathing is figuratively (and sometimes literally) restricted by my self and my environment. Iâ€™m learning how to make space for it no matter what, but the specific restriction comes down to a pattern of thought that I wrote about previously: â€œWill I be okay? Is this way of being sustainable?â€
