text_content: This thinking is so fundamental. Can I provide for myself? Can I keep myself safe, fed, and happy? Am I living in a way that is fundamentally unsustainable? If I relax now, will I be called upon to tense up to meet some need that Iâ€™m presently abandoning? Is it safe to drop my guard?On some level, I know that these existential questions are fundamentally unanswerable. At the most immediate level, the answer is â€œyes, and no.â€ Yes, I can relax. Yes I am safe. Yes, I am fed. But, thatâ€™s not the issue, is it? The issue is if I will continue to be. The issue is if what Iâ€™ve estimated about myself and the world is true, or if I will have to abandon some understanding of that in order to survive. Obviously we always will have to do so. In some sense, this is the heart of learning and growth. We shed parts of what we thought we knew and embrace the new.But... thereâ€™s a subtle quality in here that is easy to ignore. Itâ€™s about whether learning and growth feel natural and clear, or unexpected and chaotic. How long can a castle that we build stand, before somethingâ€”inside us or outsideâ€”comes along to tear it down? Or just abandons it, half-built? In my case, thereâ€™s a fundamental mistrust in there that makes even the question of â€œhow longâ€ seem fruitless. Itâ€™s never long enough, if you ask me.

This thinking is so fundamental. Can I provide for myself? Can I keep myself safe, fed, and happy? Am I living in a way that is fundamentally unsustainable? If I relax now, will I be called upon to tense up to meet some need that Iâ€™m presently abandoning? Is it safe to drop my guard?

On some level, I know that these existential questions are fundamentally unanswerable. At the most immediate level, the answer is â€œyes, and no.â€ Yes, I can relax. Yes I am safe. Yes, I am fed. But, thatâ€™s not the issue, is it? The issue is if I will continue to be. The issue is if what Iâ€™ve estimated about myself and the world is true, or if I will have to abandon some understanding of that in order to survive. Obviously we always will have to do so. In some sense, this is the heart of learning and growth. We shed parts of what we thought we knew and embrace the new.

But... thereâ€™s a subtle quality in here that is easy to ignore. Itâ€™s about whether learning and growth feel natural and clear, or unexpected and chaotic. How long can a castle that we build stand, before somethingâ€”inside us or outsideâ€”comes along to tear it down? Or just abandons it, half-built? In my case, thereâ€™s a fundamental mistrust in there that makes even the question of â€œhow longâ€ seem fruitless. Itâ€™s never long enough, if you ask me.

text_content: I want to feel and fail, controlled and uncontrolled at the same time. And yet... interfacing with other people seems to demand something else of me. It seems to demand that I compromise this effortless way of being to make space within myself and my mind for something that they need or want, conscious or otherwise.Does this make sense? I imagine not. Let me try to explain a bit more concretely.When I first started as a software developer, I was so excited to just build things, I stayed firmly in the realm of â€œwhat if.â€ Clients would ask me to build a thing, and I fixated on creating an internally coherent model of what the app should be. This was great! It made it really easy for me to just build. Unfortunately, it didnâ€™t necessarily mean that what I built would actually be useful or effective for real people.
html_content:
I want to feel and fail, controlled and uncontrolled at the same time. And yet... interfacing with other people seems to demand something else of me. It seems to demand that I compromise this effortless way of being to make space within myself and my mind for something that they need or want, conscious or otherwise.

Does this make sense? I imagine not. Let me try to explain a bit more concretely.

When I first started as a software developer, I was so excited to just build things, I stayed firmly in the realm of â€œwhat if.â€ Clients would ask me to build a thing, and I fixated on creating an internally coherent model of what the app should be. This was great! It made it really easy for me to just build. Unfortunately, it didnâ€™t necessarily mean that what I built would actually be useful or effective for real people.

text_content: Now when I talk to prospective clients, I try to ask them about their users and how they intend to use and sell the apps. I try to understand concretely what the use case is and how they know itâ€™ll be successful. They often hand-wave a lot, balking when I push back. At the end of the day, what Iâ€™m really asking for is â€œwhat is the intended net effect of what youâ€™re trying to do here?â€ If the users buy the app and use it, how is their life different? Does the net change align them more deeply with what their highest values are? Or does it just move money around, and keep them busy, letting them think theyâ€™re getting closer to what they truly want? Does it help them participate in a system whose continued growth has an extrinsic effect of making the world a more stressful, exhausting, and noisy place? Are we robbing Peter to pay Paul?No one seems to want to answer that question less than Paul, and heâ€™s always quite irritated that I donâ€™t â€œget it.â€ Oh, on the contrary, my friend, I get it. I think the world is shaped more like a Ponzi scheme than weâ€™d like to acknowledge. Itâ€™s built and runs on a collective â€œonce I...â€ fallacy, and these guys are all enlisting me to help keep the illusion going by playing my part.Not that I canâ€™t do that! I have, and I will probably continue to do so. Sometimes, the Ponzi scheme cashes out in a meaningful way for the players at all levels. The users of most of the apps I worked on had lives and families, and the benefits of the apps showed up there, for sure. And yet... they could have been so much more...

Now when I talk to prospective clients, I try to ask them about their users and how they intend to use and sell the apps. I try to understand concretely what the use case is and how they know itâ€™ll be successful. They often hand-wave a lot, balking when I push back. At the end of the day, what Iâ€™m really asking for is â€œwhat is the intended net effect of what youâ€™re trying to do here?â€ If the users buy the app and use it, how is their life different? Does the net change align them more deeply with what their highest values are? Or does it just move money around, and keep them busy, letting them think theyâ€™re getting closer to what they truly want? Does it help them participate in a system whose continued growth has an extrinsic effect of making the world a more stressful, exhausting, and noisy place? Are we robbing Peter to pay Paul?

No one seems to want to answer that question less than Paul, and heâ€™s always quite irritated that I donâ€™t â€œget it.â€ Oh, on the contrary, my friend, I get it. I think the world is shaped more like a Ponzi scheme than weâ€™d like to acknowledge. Itâ€™s built and runs on a collective â€œonce I...â€ fallacy, and these guys are all enlisting me to help keep the illusion going by playing my part.

Not that I canâ€™t do that! I have, and I will probably continue to do so. Sometimes, the Ponzi scheme cashes out in a meaningful way for the players at all levels. The users of most of the apps I worked on had lives and families, and the benefits of the apps showed up there, for sure. And yet... they could have been so much more...

text_content: Resources: A huge proportion of our economy is resources. We harvest trees, minerals, oil, and more, and we sell it to whoever wants to buy. The nice thing about this is that itâ€™s strictly necessary to do everything else, and that we can participate in the economy cleanlyâ€”the ultimate usage of the resources we provide generally arenâ€™t our responsibility, and weâ€™d be crazy to obsess over those. We just try to be the best at extracting those resources in a sustainable way at scale. Note that thereâ€™s a chain of refinement, with increasing specificity resulting from each link in the chain. Raw resource â†’ refined resources â†’ goods.Labor: Labor is kind of the opposite of a resource. Instead of putting effort into getting a material and offering it as-is, with labor weâ€™re offering a more realtime-engagement with the vision supplied by the consumer/client. They tell us what to do, and we filter that through the lens of our skills and expertise to help guide the vision to completion. For more skilled labor, this filtration is greater and greater, and some offerings are â€œproduct-plus,â€ more akin to a specialized offering with labor-enhanced customization added on (such as enterprise SaaS offerings).Specificity: A loose metric for how clearly defined the â€œproperâ€ use of a good or service is. A waffle iron has high specificity. A knife has lower specificity. Water has even lower specificity still.Impact: The crux of this inquiry. â€œImpactâ€ is an estimation of how the world is changed by the pursuit and exchange of this good or service (with a bias for â€œgood,â€ whatever that means to you).

• Resources: A huge proportion of our economy is resources. We harvest trees, minerals, oil, and more, and we sell it to whoever wants to buy. The nice thing about this is that itâ€™s strictly necessary to do everything else, and that we can participate in the economy cleanlyâ€”the ultimate usage of the resources we provide generally arenâ€™t our responsibility, and weâ€™d be crazy to obsess over those. We just try to be the best at extracting those resources in a sustainable way at scale. Note that thereâ€™s a chain of refinement, with increasing specificity resulting from each link in the chain. Raw resource â†’ refined resources â†’ goods.

  • Labor: Labor is kind of the opposite of a resource. Instead of putting effort into getting a material and offering it as-is, with labor weâ€™re offering a more realtime-engagement with the vision supplied by the consumer/client. They tell us what to do, and we filter that through the lens of our skills and expertise to help guide the vision to completion. For more skilled labor, this filtration is greater and greater, and some offerings are â€œproduct-plus,â€ more akin to a specialized offering with labor-enhanced customization added on (such as enterprise SaaS offerings).

  • Specificity: A loose metric for how clearly defined the â€œproperâ€ use of a good or service is. A waffle iron has high specificity. A knife has lower specificity. Water has even lower specificity still.

  • Impact: The crux of this inquiry. â€œImpactâ€ is an estimation of how the world is changed by the pursuit and exchange of this good or service (with a bias for â€œgood,â€ whatever that means to you).

text_content: I would summarize impact as the â€œrealistic expected value to the worldâ€ where the value is scaled by the realism AND the potential impact, with both positive value and unhedged risk all baked in.This requires that we:Define and articulate what is â€œgoodâ€Consider what the immediate and long term results of our successful efforts are (how much do these align with what is â€œgoodâ€?)Consider the cost of our unsuccessful efforts, as well as the interim effortsConsider the likelihood of our successI am ridiculously obsessive about this, perhaps traumatically so, and it seems like thereâ€™s not a lot of room for that in business. Itâ€™s either people who want to feel better about what they are doing (which devolved into virtue signaling), or people who are trying to sell others on their worldview over anyone elseâ€™s (â€œIâ€™ve thought through, and this is for sure how itâ€™s going to go and itâ€™s going to be a net good for humanityâ€ *waves hands furtively*).
html_content:
I would summarize impact as the â€œrealistic expected value to the worldâ€ where the value is scaled by the realism AND the potential impact, with both positive value and unhedged risk all baked in.

This requires that we:

  • Define and articulate what is â€œgoodâ€

  • Consider what the immediate and long term results of our successful efforts are (how much do these align with what is â€œgoodâ€?)

  • Consider the cost of our unsuccessful efforts, as well as the interim efforts

  • Consider the likelihood of our success

text_content: The next day, my back was in even more pain than before. What gives!? I assume its soreness from the adjustment, and maybe some compensatory posture Iâ€™ve taken while sitting and lying down. It happens, I suppose. But, as the day wore on, it got worse and worse. At nightfall, I was at a breaking point, feeling so aggrieved.I feel like itâ€™s important to be honest and complete here, so Iâ€™ll share that yes, I took a psychedelic. I donâ€™t want to unduly encourage their use, but they have been quite helpful to me. Itâ€™s probably the way my brain and attention work. Iâ€™m... quite avoidant, so sometimes these drugs are the only thing that can wrest my attention away from my mind and put it on whatâ€™s actually in frontâ€”or insideâ€”of me. I was hoping to connect with â€œwhat the hell is wrong with me?â€ Apparently, a lot. At first, I only felt the overwhelming pain. It was clear, immediately, that I had been distracting myself from the full intensity of what was going on in my body. As it came into focus, I felt like I was going to die, like I was actually edging closer to death and breakdown. How could I not interpret this unbearable pain like that? It brought me to my knees, and all I could do is writhe and laugh, uncomfortably, at how incapacitated I was. After that passed, I realized I needed to dive a little deeper. I would sit, and I would ask, of God, the universe, reality itself: â€œWhy is this happening to me? What is going on here?â€

text_content: I closed my eyes and the sensation washed over me. I could see darkness, and colors and shapes swirling in the darkness, coming together to form what looked and felt like bony gears, of deep purple and green, poised and ready to grind me, bones, flesh, and being, into mush. I could feel the message dawning on my mind, â€œYouâ€™re so prideful. Look at how you even approach Me. Posturing and pensive, like I owe you an answer. Look at the stance of your heart.â€ I could feel it. I knew it was that way. I hung my head and looked at my feet. I would be humble! Oh, if only I knew how! But itâ€™s so hardâ€”I want desperately to know where my spot is, so that I could just take it.Even now, I feel the singe of sadness rising up to my nose and eyes. Yes, Iâ€™m guilty of pride, but itâ€™s more than that. I want to be... in charge of my own destiny. I want to be my own man. Iâ€™m guilty of holding out my heart to the extent that noone else can touch it. Itâ€™s a peculiar kind of pride, because it doesnâ€™t require anyone else participate in my self-delusion. Rather, it requires that they do not participate! Leave me alone! I am sovereign! Let me be a god only in my own mind! Itâ€™s mine! Leave me be!!

text_content: It is a paradox in the whole matter of humility that when a man knows his own worth he comes close to being a victim of pride and yet humility cannot mean that a man has to imagine that he is less worthy than he really is. Self-delusion is no virtue and is presumably to be as much avoided as any other delusion by the seeker after truth. â€œThe last infirmity of great mindsâ€ is not easily conquered.https://www.myjewishlearning.com/article/humility-in-judaism/I can see how this leaks out in painful ways, in ways that undermine the love and support and encouragement I offer to others. Itâ€™s a subtle thing, for sure. I offer love and encouragement, but I hold something back. I hold me back. Itâ€™s fractional reserve love. I borrow against myself and give, but I hold something back, some essence of me. What this means is that when the bills come due, I come up short. I can see how this makes me a... hard person to do the business of love and friendship with. It certainly makes me impossible to keep books with. To settle up with... ever.

text_content: Reeling from that realization, I decided again to dive in once more. I sat and watched as my vision blurred and went fuzzy. My visual system reverting into a more haywire state, as the chairs, tables, and lights before me jumped erratically to and fro. This feeling is fond and familiar; oh how I love the rawness and the indeterminacy of that mode of seeing and feeling. And feeling too! I could feel my body and skin and sensations, all chaotically clamoring for attention, with apparently no gatekeeper process to tell them to simmer down or to shut them out. At first it is overwhelming, and then it settles and settles, slowly returning to normal. Itâ€™s quite the trip, every time. The interesting thing, though, is not the craziness of the sensory storm. The interesting thing is where my mind chooses to stroll, as the chaos dies down.In this instance, as my faculties were returning, I could feel myself as a single human being in a human body, awash in this placeâ€”and that I love! That is enough! That I would take, for a thousand years or even more! And yet, itâ€™s not merely that. Iâ€™m twisted around. My back and arm hurts. I could feel my left arm, repeatedly clamping and clenching its fist, as if it had a mind of its own. And it should! Itâ€™s played second fiddle to my right arm for over three decades! The choices Iâ€™ve made have led to such pain and suffering, which Iâ€™ve strangely and gladly carried as some kind of penance! No wonder my other half is so indignant! He would have done all of this so differently.

â€œWe need to do a project together,â€ he finally spoke. â€œWe need to make something...â€

Can I be me? In all my forms? What parts are me? What parts are not? In some ways, the exponential effort to author an answer to this question may be the only part persisting it at all, now. Who am I without my self-doubt? Would I be safe? Oops! Thatâ€™s the self-doubt talking!And therein lies my rub. And it hasnâ€™t stopped since.

text_content: So who cares?Well, the need to circumvent this fundamental nature of reality has infected every aspect of my being. Instead of accepting that good things come to an end in good timeâ€”sometimes partially, sometimes completelyâ€”Iâ€™ve taken it on to modify my patchwork puppet to try to perfectly model the nature of things, in the vain and tragic hope that they can not end.If anything, this makes me MORE prone to more tumult, because the desperation to find and prove ways in which the things Iâ€™m trying now are not going to end in disappointment, or that they are going to end in predictable ways that I can insulate myself from or even learn to sidestep with enough practice, causes me to choose things that: (1) were never â€œstartedâ€ to begin with, existing entirely or in part in my mind; or (2) are more likely to end because Iâ€™m more focused on my strategy than I am on the things themselves.

text_content: On returning homeIâ€™m hesitant to share any detail about my family. I donâ€™t think my characterizations are particularly helpful, nor are they complete, so anything I say will probably be prejudicial in a way that doesnâ€™t serve my purpose here. Iâ€™ll limit myself to saying that theyâ€™re each struggling with different things in their own ways. As am I. The difference is that their struggles have seemed to bind them more closely together, whereas mine have driven me away from them, restlessly searching the world for my deliverance. I only recently discovered the twin truths: (1) the relief I seek wonâ€™t be found â€œout there,â€ and (2) my environment (including my own behaviors that keep it to a specific manner) is the hidden factor limiting my ability to get free.Itâ€™s with that lens that I approach the members of family, hoping not to push my perspectives and beliefs on them, as I have in the past, but to offer some kindness, co-regulation, and some cognitive scratch space, that they might get a little bit more free, while I try to, too.

text_content: Anyway, what I noticed about myself while I was there is a critical piece that I already knew but hadnâ€™t paid enough attention to because distractions got in the way. In fact, it was because I was there at a time when things started to go south on a national scale that I wasnâ€™t able to self-insulate sufficiently. The perfect storm of my family being affected by the rhetoric on social media alongside my own frustration with my inability to focus in such a chaotic environmentâ€”six other people living in one house, all moving through the common area in which I set up my â€œworkstationâ€â€”gave me the perfect opportunity to observe a pattern of my own more clearly.The pattern was thus: I would observe myself in a focused, calm, and attentive state, sometimes for hours at a time, and then, once the immediate â€taskâ€ went away and nothing sufficient took its place in short order, I would find myself overwhelmed with fatigue and frustration. Whoa! What gives?My assumption is that thereâ€™s some pattern of holding that enables me to suppress feelings of stress build up, in some cases enabling even fiercer focusing, and this creates the perfect storm. As I noticed this, I watched it take effect, and I resolved to catch it and back off more frequently. Bodily cues are good, not impairing. I am learning how to let my body enter the â€œlast mileâ€ (oh god I hope it is the last one) of my ways of being, the two that are the trickiest: (1) working and (2) connection.

The perfect storm of my family being affected by the rhetoric on social media alongside my own frustration with my inability to focus in such a chaotic environmentâ€”six other people living in one house, all moving through the common area in which I set up my â€œworkstationâ€â€”gave me the perfect opportunity to observe a pattern of my own more clearly.

The pattern was thus: I would observe myself in a focused, calm, and attentive state, sometimes for hours at a time, and then, once the immediate â€taskâ€ went away and nothing sufficient took its place in short order, I would find myself overwhelmed with fatigue and frustration. Whoa! What gives?

My assumption is that thereâ€™s some pattern of holding that enables me to suppress feelings of stress build up, in some cases enabling even fiercer focusing, and this creates the perfect storm. As I noticed this, I watched it take effect, and I resolved to catch it and back off more frequently. Bodily cues are good, not impairing. I am learning how to let my body enter the â€œlast mileâ€ (oh god I hope it is the last one) of my ways of being, the two that are the trickiest: (1) working and (2) connection.

text_content: The irony is, like a lot of the other work Iâ€™ve done, this will likely succeed and backfire in much the same way. Itâ€™ll succeed in the sense that, once freed, my energy and natural inclinations will contribute to the flow, enjoyment, and sustainability of what I do. Itâ€™ll backfire in the sense that a lot of what I currently do will probably fall away, in part or in whole. That is the cost of transformation, as we know. We must say goodbye to the bad fits.So thatâ€™s the work for now. Itâ€™s going well, albeit slow. Thatâ€™s pretty much par for the course. Learning by feeling and doing. It will take time, and then settle into a groove, as most things tend to.

text_content: My current fixationsAs Iâ€™ve brought out some of my anger and frustration, some of my old desires have returned. Some things I want to build are returning to my attention. Some of the frustrations with things that Iâ€™ve learned well how to put up with areâ€¦ taking me, again. Iâ€™m glad. Theyâ€™re welcome back in. Those things can get fucked. I donâ€™t mind.Iâ€™m not sure if I want to go into a lot of detail right now. Hereâ€™s a current list of things I am looking at:Fauxcumentary about the â€œpodcast to callâ€ pipeline, and some rudimentary tools to prove it can workTelegram bot â€voice note to selfâ€ bot that can take the place of a journal and Twitter on the goTwitter alternative that focuses on 1:1 engagement rather than the free-for-all piss-off that we have nowA LLM-enhanced generative UI app paradigm for data and collaboration, to make it easier to have and explore interesting ideas and avenues togetherThe challenge with these is that I have to simultaneously work on not slipping into the hyperfixation trap, lest they turn bitter in my hands and drive me away like ghosts.We will see.
html_content:
My current fixations

As Iâ€™ve brought out some of my anger and frustration, some of my old desires have returned. Some things I want to build are returning to my attention. Some of the frustrations with things that Iâ€™ve learned well how to put up with areâ€¦ taking me, again. Iâ€™m glad. Theyâ€™re welcome back in. Those things can get fucked. I donâ€™t mind.

Iâ€™m not sure if I want to go into a lot of detail right now. Hereâ€™s a current list of things I am looking at:

  1. Fauxcumentary about the â€œpodcast to callâ€ pipeline, and some rudimentary tools to prove it can work

  2. Telegram bot â€voice note to selfâ€ bot that can take the place of a journal and Twitter on the go

  3. Twitter alternative that focuses on 1:1 engagement rather than the free-for-all piss-off that we have now

  4. A LLM-enhanced generative UI app paradigm for data and collaboration, to make it easier to have and explore interesting ideas and avenues together

The challenge with these is that I have to simultaneously work on not slipping into the hyperfixation trap, lest they turn bitter in my hands and drive me away like ghosts.

We will see.

text_content: OverviewDefender and I dive deep into one of the most frustrating patterns in creative work: the tension between having ideas and actually finishing things. We explore why growth often requires moving away from immediate rewards, how our brains get hijacked by easier dopamine hits (like Twitter), and the fundamental challenge of building sustainable momentum when you're naturally drawn to the next shiny idea.This conversation gets into the weeds of energy management, the psychology of "idea addiction," and practical strategies for breaking through the cycle of starting projects without finishing them. We also touch on the philosophical question of whether there's a place for us in the world, and how that drives everything from project selection to collaboration patterns.If you've ever found yourself stuck between the excitement of new ideas and the grinding reality of execution, this one's for you.I drove the tldraw today, so there was a lot less going on in this one. ğŸ˜…
html_content:
Overview

Defender and I dive deep into one of the most frustrating patterns in creative work: the tension between having ideas and actually finishing things. We explore why growth often requires moving away from immediate rewards, how our brains get hijacked by easier dopamine hits (like Twitter), and the fundamental challenge of building sustainable momentum when you're naturally drawn to the next shiny idea.

This conversation gets into the weeds of energy management, the psychology of "idea addiction," and practical strategies for breaking through the cycle of starting projects without finishing them. We also touch on the philosophical question of whether there's a place for us in the world, and how that drives everything from project selection to collaboration patterns.

If you've ever found yourself stuck between the excitement of new ideas and the grinding reality of execution, this one's for you.

heading: Overview

text_content: Chapters[00:00:00] The Valley of GrowthWe start with Defender's core insight: growth is inherently difficult and uncomfortable, but when you have easier reward systems available (like social media), you face an unnatural choice between immediate gratification and long-term progress. This sets up the central tension of the entire conversation.When you put energy into Twitter or other â€œdistractions,â€ the energy tends to dissipate. Insights and valuable inputs may percolate back in, like rain, too.[00:03:27] Energy Management and DysregulationI share my model for tracking energy levels throughout the day, explaining how I've learned to recognize when I'm dysregulated (even when I feel "in control") and why pushing too hard leads to diminishing returns. We discuss the difference between physiological stress and mental energy depletion.An old diagram I drew to try to visualize my felt energy and focus throughout the day. Differentiating between energy level and nervous system capacity/dysregulation is important. Just because youâ€™re feeling hyped doesnâ€™t mean you can actually focus.[00:08:41] The Cheap Energy TrapDefender introduces the concept of "cheap energy" - temporary bumps that feel rewarding but don't actually sustain you. We explore how these compete with the deeper, more sustainable rewards that come from actual growth and flow states.
html_content:
Chapters

[00:00:00] The Valley of Growth

We start with Defender's core insight: growth is inherently difficult and uncomfortable, but when you have easier reward systems available (like social media), you face an unnatural choice between immediate gratification and long-term progress. This sets up the central tension of the entire conversation.

[00:03:27] Energy Management and Dysregulation

I share my model for tracking energy levels throughout the day, explaining how I've learned to recognize when I'm dysregulated (even when I feel "in control") and why pushing too hard leads to diminishing returns. We discuss the difference between physiological stress and mental energy depletion.

[00:08:41] The Cheap Energy Trap

Defender introduces the concept of "cheap energy" - temporary bumps that feel rewarding but don't actually sustain you. We explore how these compete with the deeper, more sustainable rewards that come from actual growth and flow states.

heading: Chapters

text_content: Theorizing that the way we draw down our energy/tax our nervous systems matters and produces dramatically different results each day. Iâ€™m sure this is a well-researched area of study, but what Iâ€™m really craving is a personal curriculum to figure it out for oneself.[00:14:55] Breaking Projects Into Sustainable PiecesWe dig into why big ambitious projects often fail and how successful work tends to fit into existing patterns rather than requiring complete life restructuring. Defender shares insights about carving out small, manageable pieces that can actually get completed.Twitter and other activities can draw attention away from big projects. Reframing the big project as a culmination of a lot of smaller parts is one strategy to make it more cost-competitive with catchy distractions.[00:21:02] The Trust Problem with Yourself Defender makes a brilliant analogy about losing trust in yourself like you would with an unreliable coworker. When you repeatedly start and abandon projects, parts of your brain start expecting failure. This creates a self-reinforcing cycle that's hard to break.Being an Idea Guyâ„¢ is not a bad thing, but balancing out that extreme reliance on ideas and de-biasing the psyche from reaching for ideas as an escape/buffer IS the challenge.[00:25:43] Idea Addiction and the ADHD Brain

text_content: I open up about how having ideas has become a coping mechanism - it feels good to be in that space of possibility, but it can become pathological when you're just "doping yourself up" before doing any actual work. We explore the casino-like nature of constantly chasing new ideas.[00:27:32] The Wood Carving AnalogyDefender reframes the whole thing: what if having ideas is just your hobby, like wood carving? The problem only arises when you want your hobby to serve other goals, like making money or shipping products. This leads to a deeper discussion about aligning activities with intrinsic motivation.[00:30:24] Zooming In vs. Zooming OutWe talk about training your ADHD brain to generate ideas within the scope of your current project rather than constantly jumping to new domains. The key is channeling that same creative energy but within boundaries.Defender loves â€œzooming inâ€ as a way to focus and get things done. I agree, but I find that the ideas manage to seep inside and distract me, too.[00:33:33] The Motivational Structure ProblemI share how my entire reward system might be "unhinged" - getting dopamine from ideas before doing work, then being disappointed when reality doesn't match imagination. It's like promising a kid a cookie for good behavior, then not delivering.[00:36:30] Intrinsic vs. Extrinsic MotivationWe explore the difference between woodworkers who genuinely enjoy every step of the process versus people motivated by external goals. The question becomes: how do you find joy in the actual work, not just the vision?
html_content:
I open up about how having ideas has become a coping mechanism - it feels good to be in that space of possibility, but it can become pathological when you're just "doping yourself up" before doing any actual work. We explore the casino-like nature of constantly chasing new ideas.

[00:27:32] The Wood Carving Analogy

Defender reframes the whole thing: what if having ideas is just your hobby, like wood carving? The problem only arises when you want your hobby to serve other goals, like making money or shipping products. This leads to a deeper discussion about aligning activities with intrinsic motivation.

[00:30:24] Zooming In vs. Zooming Out

We talk about training your ADHD brain to generate ideas within the scope of your current project rather than constantly jumping to new domains. The key is channeling that same creative energy but within boundaries.

[00:33:33] The Motivational Structure Problem

I share how my entire reward system might be "unhinged" - getting dopamine from ideas before doing work, then being disappointed when reality doesn't match imagination. It's like promising a kid a cookie for good behavior, then not delivering.

[00:36:30] Intrinsic vs. Extrinsic Motivation

We explore the difference between woodworkers who genuinely enjoy every step of the process versus people motivated by external goals. The question becomes: how do you find joy in the actual work, not just the vision?

It's like letting a kid's temper tantrum play out instead of giving them a cookie.[00:46:31] The Gentle vs. Disciplined ApproachWe debate whether the solution is more self-compassion or more structure. [00:40:11] Collaboration as a Solution

Defender suggests that collaborating with others can naturally enhance the reward of execution because "connecting feels really good." This becomes a recurring theme about how external accountability and shared excitement can overcome individual willpower issues.

[00:41:45] Sitting with the Discomfort

I describe my approach of "unplugging" and letting my brain "stew" - basically allowing myself to feel the discomfort of not getting immediate gratification until new patterns emerge. It's like letting a kid's temper tantrum play out instead of giving them a cookie.

[00:46:31] The Gentle vs. Disciplined Approach

We debate whether the solution is more self-compassion or more structure. Defender advocates for increasing rewards rather than just applying willpower, framing it as a physics problem of friction and incentives.

[00:48:33] The Fundamental Question

I get philosophical about what we're really trying to answer: "Is there a place for me in this world?" Everything we do is essentially testing whether our ideas and way of being can be received and valued by reality.

[00:52:01] Reducing Scaffolding Friction

Defender shares insights about how much "red" (setup, boilerplate, deployment) prevents him from starting projects. We discuss strategies for minimizing friction through reusable foundations and single-file apps.

text_content: Defender highlighted the difference (left) between working on foundational stuff like folders and deployment pipelines (red), and fun, innovative stuff like the apps we want to build (green). I pointed out that we could split up the apps into little standalone features and components that we could build and share separately (right).[00:57:18] The Foundation Builders vs. Idea PeopleWe create a visual model distinguishing between people who work on foundational infrastructure, those who build applications, and those who operate in the "stratosphere" of ideas. Each layer has different rewards and challenges.I took the last example and ran way too far with it. The idea here is that there are different strata, and different brain types like sticking in different areas. The key is to figure out how to coordinate with (and maybe incentivize that coordination for) those working above and below you.[01:06:37] The Spaceship ProblemDefender introduces the "leapfrogging" dilemma: if you start building something that will take two weeks, but you might have a better idea in a few days, do you wait or commit? This captures the core challenge of when to stick versus when to switch.[01:11:17] The To-Do List and CollaborationDefender shows his current project list and shares his experience mentoring Code Day students. We discuss whether managing others' work is "cheating" or just a different kind of productivity, and the importance of staying close to the actual building process.[01:16:23] Voluntary Transparency and Decision-Making

[00:57:18] The Foundation Builders vs. Idea People

We create a visual model distinguishing between people who work on foundational infrastructure, those who build applications, and those who operate in the "stratosphere" of ideas. Each layer has different rewards and challenges.

Defender introduces the "leapfrogging" dilemma: if you start building something that will take two weeks, but you might have a better idea in a few days, do you wait or commit? This captures the core challenge of when to stick versus when to switch.

Defender shows his current project list and shares his experience mentoring Code Day students. We discuss whether managing others' work is "cheating" or just a different kind of productivity, and the importance of staying close to the actual building process.

text_content: Dear Joshua,Hey! Happy belated birthday. I guess itâ€™s only been a couple of days for you. For me, itâ€™s been a whole year! You wouldnâ€™t believe what Iâ€™ve been through. Seriously. You spend so much time encouraging other people to have self-compassion and give themselves a break, and thatâ€™s great, but are you really doing the same thing for yourself? Are you really treating yourself like a living, breathing human being, and not just some magical avatar? Are you really asking yourself, directly, clearly, â€œwhat do I need right now,â€ and then actually giving it to yourself? I know that there has been a couple of times over the last few days whereâ€™s its occurred to you (rest, slowing down, putting down the phone), and that youâ€™ve actually done it, but Iâ€™m not kidding or underselling it when I say this is the single greatest thing holding you back, and every little bit of progress you can make will compound over the course of the next year. If you can please just prioritize this starting now, I know youâ€™ll be grateful. I certainly am.

text_content: Second, take some time to feel. I know you like to feel as you go, and I know thatâ€™s been working really well for you, but please take some walks. Please put down the phone and the voice notes and the thinking and planning, and just wander and let your mind do the same. Please. I know itâ€™s hard. I know youâ€™re drowning in â€œcouldsâ€ and â€œwhat ifs.â€ They will still all be here, exactly as you left them, when you return. I promise. I wonâ€™t let anyone budge them. However, they may shrink when youâ€™re not watching. I canâ€™t promise that they wonâ€™t. You'll be glad, though. The shrinkage will create more room for more stuff, ultimately, and eventually itâ€™ll be only the right stuff. That feeling will be like NO other. When your entire life is filled with the right stuff, youâ€™ll feel like a fish in temperate water. Just right as rain. Please give it the space to fill in.

text_content: Okay, my third and final ask: Please take time to appreciate people more. You donâ€™t have to be effusive or expressive about it (unless you want to), but you do need to actually put your heart there. You spend so much time focused on being something for people, that youâ€™re really starving them and yourself of just being with them, as you. You know what I mean? Youâ€™re missing the trees for the forest, bro! What, youâ€™re going to wait until youâ€™re perfect and everyone else is perfect and everythingâ€™s amazing to truly bask in the joy and reverie? Are you serious? Iâ€™m not saying you have to drop everything and all of your Great Work and do only this from now on, but you can get away with a HECK of a lot more right now than you are. Maybe 200% more. Seriously. Just... do it. Just love these people. You already do! Just let yourself trip out on it. It doesnâ€™t matter if you miss an insight or you forget to make progress or you lose your place in conversation. You and they will appreciate this way more than anything else, so please just love them and let yourself feel it. It is OKAY. It is very, very OKAY.Alright. Thanks for hearing me out. I wish I had more time, but it's getting late here and I really want to fire this off before I go to sleep. I love you, Iâ€™m proud of you, and Iâ€™m so grateful to you for continuing to show up, do the work, and look for more. You have no idea how happy that makes me. You are a truly wonderful human being, and Iâ€™m grateful to share this existence with you. Keep it up! Keep being you. But, like, more. ğŸ˜…Love and grace,Joshua

text_content: OverviewDefender and I dive deep into consciousness, agency, and decision-making across different scales - from individual awareness to collective intelligence. We explore how intuitive and rational modes of thinking interact, why micromanaging (whether in companies or in our own minds) creates problems, and how attention itself might be the most underrated tool for change.The conversation weaves through ant colonies solving problems, the relationship between love and competence, and how we might map the emerging field of collective cognition. We introduce concepts like â€œsurface vs solveâ€ in information systems and discuss why friction and resistance might be necessary features, not bugs, in human systems.
html_content:
Overview

Defender and I dive deep into consciousness, agency, and decision-making across different scales - from individual awareness to collective intelligence. We explore how intuitive and rational modes of thinking interact, why micromanaging (whether in companies or in our own minds) creates problems, and how attention itself might be the most underrated tool for change.

The conversation weaves through ant colonies solving problems, the relationship between love and competence, and how we might map the emerging field of collective cognition. We introduce concepts like â€œsurface vs solveâ€ in information systems and discuss why friction and resistance might be necessary features, not bugs, in human systems.

text_content: Chapters[00:00:00] Stream vs Evergreen KnowledgeWe set up the whiteboard to distinguish between transient "stream" content and evergreen repositories. Defender introduces the challenge of creating lasting knowledge when ideas don't fit into neat boxes, and we discuss how desire paths form through actual use rather than planning.Stream content is whatever weâ€™re working on and writing right now, which typically shows up in a feed. Evergreen content is the â€œbody of work,â€ more akin to published and curated library of output. Desire paths (left) are people-worn paths that sometimes cut through where the designed paths ignore.[00:07:00] Agency and Free Will - Where Decisions Actually Get MadeWe tackle the question of where decisions originate - at what level of awareness do choices actually happen? Using the ant colony video as a launching point, we explore how individual agents contribute to collective decisions they can't see or understand.The question of â€œwhat are decisions and where and how are they madeâ€ is a fascinating one. We examine how ants and humans make collective decisions during problem-solving, and turn that introspection on awareness and agency itself.[00:15:00] Intuitive vs Rational CognitionDefender breaks down two fundamental modes: intuitive (holistic, seeing the whole frame) and rational (sequential, problem-solving within a frame). We discuss how these aren't opposites but interleaved bands of awareness that work together, and how being stuck in either mode creates different kinds of problems.

text_content: The questions of â€œwhat is intuitive thinkingâ€ and â€œwhat is rational thinkingâ€ are fascinating and may have counterintuitive and irrational-seeming answers. Characterizing them as themes or genres rather than specific, limited procedures or approaches may prove to be a more fruitful frame for analysis.[00:34:00] The Customer Support MetaphorWe develop an extended metaphor: when a company's stock is in freefall, the customer support person leaving their station to "fix" things creates three problems instead of one. This becomes a framework for understanding why acting outside your level of awareness often makes things worse.Human beings have interesting failure modes that we often miss until the mistake is made, including abandoning our posts to try to help before we fully understand the nature of the problem weâ€™re hoping to solve. Many such cases! The â€œmidwit curveâ€ might be better termed the â€œawareness curve.â€[00:45:00] Reading the Egregore - Hard Drive vs Swap SpaceI introduce the concept of people having "hard drives" (their individual self) and "swap space" (shared cultural/ideological programming). We discuss how to detect when you're talking to someone versus talking to the ideology they're channeling, and why this matters for genuine connection.

text_content: The superego, or the part of the mind that is focused on social relations, can be thought of as a mechanism for modeling the collective egregores and hosting oneâ€™s strategy for relating to them. Ultimately, I suspect that the superego is not eternally necessary, and that swap space can largely be freed up as the individuation of the self is accomplished.[00:56:00] Surface vs SolveDefender explains a crucial distinction: systems that solve problems for you (black box) versus systems that surface information for your decision. We connect this to everything from AI assistants to side mirrors, exploring why solving without transparency creates fragility.The idea of â€œsurfacingâ€ is such a critical one for group coordination and collective evolution. Defender illustrates how he might advocate for the mapping and inclusion of new territory within ORI, whereas I might pull in a different direction. The aggregate coverage of the collective shifts through this effectively Brownian motion, similarly to what happens with political discourse on social media.[01:03:00] Loving Attention as CEO ResourceWe discover that loving attention - whether from a CEO to employees or from your conscious mind to your body - might be the most underutilized tool for positive change. The key insight: attention without agency capture, just showing up with "I want us both to be okay."Egregores, human selves, and nearly all of our coordinating efforts are guided and fueled by attention. The amount and nature of the attention seems to have a profound impact on the way that these phenomena develop.

text_content: [01:14:00] Love, Competence, and Resource ConstraintsWe explore how competence emerges from love, and how resource scarcity drives organisms (whether people or companies) toward fear-based decisions. We touch on how some forms of extreme competence develop without love, creating amoral excellence.â€œResourcesâ€ and the sense of resource availability seems to be the dominant influence on the manner in which that attention is dolled out. Love naturally produces competence, while cruelty, abuse, and neglect occasionally serve as a forcing function for a particularly kind of amoral competence that must naturally face its own reckoning (the â€œDarth Vaderâ€ effect).[01:20:00] The ORI Org Chart - Mapping Collaborative SpaceDefender reveals his emerging "org chart for Spaceship Earth" - not a hierarchy but a rotating circle of collaborators. We discuss how everyone should make their own map of the field, and how these personal perspectives might mesh into collective understanding.Defender is working on his own org chart, a whoâ€™s who of people working on things relevant to his interests. If this catches on, distributed directories of â€œcoworkersâ€ may be the future of collaborative coordination.The conversation represents an attempt to develop language and frameworks for understanding collective cognition while preserving the magic - answering deep questions about consciousness and free will without reducing everything to mechanical explanations. We're essentially seeding the conversations we hope will become common in the emerging field of memetics and collective intelligence.

text_content: Note: This article contains mentions of drug use. I donâ€™t condone nor suggest you use this or other drugs. Itâ€™s a personal decision, obviously, and I would ask that if you do pursue this or similar drugs, you do so through official, legal channels that you can trust, with guidance and support from trained people who have guided others before and have all of the resources to support you both during and afterwards. These kind of things can and do mess people up. It could happen to you. Iâ€™ve had a close call. It is not worth it. If only this once, learn from advice, and not your own inevitable mistakes, please.Last night I did DMT for the first time in months. I had been holding out because I didnâ€™t think I needed it. So much material was coming up in my daily experienceâ€”sensations, emotions, conditioningâ€”that I thought stirring the pot with a psychedelic would only make things harder and more complicated. I managed to make a lot of progress without any chemical assistance, including caffeine, which Iâ€™ve been off of for three weeks. It's been great.And yet, I found myself slip into some... â€œoldâ€ feelings. Some familiar reflections on the nature of my life and my status in it. These were the exact same kind of gap-creating feelings that had so subsided as I launched myself full-bore, headfirst into the things I love and delight in. Conversations with Defender, heartfelt tweets, deep, long, and varied conversations with so many people across my life, little momentary art projects that spark joy... all of these were so newly satisfying and fulfillingâ€”until they werenâ€™t.

text_content: Itâ€™s not that they are not enough. On the contrary, they are all Iâ€™ve ever wanted. I feel more aligned than I ever have been. My expressions and writing are honest, earnest, and true. I feel like Iâ€™m being carried on a conveyor towards an Ultimate Destiny which is as beautiful and vivid as it is mundane and simple. I am happy.And yet... my body still pains me. Iâ€™m tired. Iâ€™m achey.1 Iâ€™m not in the shape I desire. How can I count myself among the truly happy if my level of embodiment is in the double-digits? It makes sense that my mind has organized itself around this New Normal, but my body has yet to get the message. It is this concern that seeded the intention in my mind.I want to share a few insights from the trips.

text_content: Trip 1: Feeling the tensionI just did some DMT, and I can feel all this tension in my chest and neckâ€”especially at the base of my skull where my neck connects. There's so much tension there just holding my head steady, and itâ€™s likeâ€¦ oh my God. I wiggled and rocked, stretched through it, and it feels better now. But it hurts. I feel so tired. So fucking tired. Thereâ€™s this massive tension throughout my system just holding me still, containing meâ€”containing Joshua. The current Joshua is maybe 5% of the full Joshua. Thatâ€™s okay. That's where Iâ€™m at right now. That's just where Iâ€™m at.God, Iâ€™m so tired. Just feeling all of it. Really feeling it. And thenâ€”yeah, I feel so good. My lids are heavy. I can barely talk. I just want to go into a trance.Iâ€™m so lucky to be alive. So lucky to be alive. So lucky.Oh, man.Itâ€™s not a massive reveal, honestly, but the clarity with which I felt the tension holding my neck in place, on both sides of my head was sharp! I sit a lot, for many hours at my desk, often in a kneeling chair. This causes me to hold my back and neck in certain, perhaps pathological, ways. It may be time to begin standing some of the time. Let me try that now...Oh yeah. Thatâ€™s nice.Look at me. I have so many options available to me, and I hardly use them. This feels great. html_content:
Trip 1: Feeling the tension

I just did some DMT, and I can feel all this tension in my chest and neckâ€”especially at the base of my skull where my neck connects. There's so much tension there just holding my head steady, and itâ€™s likeâ€¦ oh my God. I wiggled and rocked, stretched through it, and it feels better now. But it hurts. I feel so tired. So fucking tired. Thereâ€™s this massive tension throughout my system just holding me still, containing meâ€”containing Joshua. The current Joshua is maybe 5% of the full Joshua. Thatâ€™s okay. That's where Iâ€™m at right now. That's just where Iâ€™m at.

God, Iâ€™m so tired. Just feeling all of it. Really feeling it. And thenâ€”yeah, I feel so good. My lids are heavy. I can barely talk. I just want to go into a trance.

Iâ€™m so lucky to be alive. So lucky to be alive. So lucky.

Oh, man.

Itâ€™s not a massive reveal, honestly, but the clarity with which I felt the tension holding my neck in place, on both sides of my head was sharp! I sit a lot, for many hours at my desk, often in a kneeling chair. This causes me to hold my back and neck in certain, perhaps pathological, ways. It may be time to begin standing some of the time. Let me try that now...

Oh yeah. Thatâ€™s nice.

Look at me. I have so many options available to me, and I hardly use them. This feels great. I probably also want to remount my monitor on the arm I bought, so I can raise it by a few inches over the stand. Itâ€™s just a little low right now. Little changes can have such a profound effect.

And yeah, I need to move more. Itâ€™s easier to dance at my desk when Iâ€™m standing. ğŸ˜

Moving on.

text_content: Trip 2: No schedule or planThe rush came over me and I felt like I was in a procession, like a biblical pilgrim angling through the crowd to see Jesus or something. And then it was my turn; the spotlightâ€™s on me nowâ€”what do I do?For a minute I was scrambling. This moment seeped into my bones. I felt the wave of attention and pressure coming over me. What am I supposed to do? I need to feel through it. And I did. I handled it, held it, felt it. After it passed, I thought about doing more, and then I thought to myself, â€œWaitâ€”no, you handled it. You werenâ€™t overwhelmed. That's a good thing.â€It made me reflect on what the spotlight feels like. My biggest fear is being shut down because I went overboard, slipping out of control. So when attention comes on me, all this tension shows up to make sure things go â€œaccording to plan.â€But in that moment I let go and realized: itâ€™s okay. You can take time. Take up your space. And then I realized: thereâ€™s no way anything was supposed to go. That's not how God plays. Things are highly deterministic, but thereâ€™s no universally scripted direction, no grand plan down to the letter. Whatever comes out is lawfulâ€”more resiliently and enduringly lawful than if something were supposed to go a certain way.Whew.
html_content:
Trip 2: No schedule or plan

The rush came over me and I felt like I was in a procession, like a biblical pilgrim angling through the crowd to see Jesus or something. And then it was my turn; the spotlightâ€™s on me nowâ€”what do I do?

For a minute I was scrambling. This moment seeped into my bones. I felt the wave of attention and pressure coming over me. What am I supposed to do? I need to feel through it. And I did. I handled it, held it, felt it. After it passed, I thought about doing more, and then I thought to myself, â€œWaitâ€”no, you handled it. You werenâ€™t overwhelmed. That's a good thing.â€

It made me reflect on what the spotlight feels like. My biggest fear is being shut down because I went overboard, slipping out of control. So when attention comes on me, all this tension shows up to make sure things go â€œaccording to plan.â€

But in that moment I let go and realized: itâ€™s okay. You can take time. Take up your space. And then I realized: thereâ€™s no way anything was supposed to go. That's not how God plays. Things are highly deterministic, but thereâ€™s no universally scripted direction, no grand plan down to the letter. Whatever comes out is lawfulâ€”more resiliently and enduringly lawful than if something were supposed to go a certain way.

Whew.

text_content: This one was the reason I wanted to write this at all. That moment of realization, that there was no way that things were supposed to go, and all of these habits of mind that had come from church, class, and all manner of â€œeventsâ€ that felt like they had a defined rhythm that I didnâ€™t fit in, this had all come from some miscalculations about how I was supposed to be, which I have been dutifully been holding in place with restrictive habits of mind and motions of body. I donâ€™t think these things are fully and properly dispelled with one clear viewing, like this, but it is my hope that they will loosens and subside, over time, and that I can get closer and closer to becoming 100% Joshua, even if heâ€™s turns out to be so unintelligible and hard to follow that he derails anything he joins.We can have a little derailment, as a treat.

text_content: On the 5% Joshua thing... 100% Joshua would be completely fluid and probably semi-intelligible at best. I think people would have a hard time understanding it. I might not engage with everything for as long or as deeply as I do now.Right now at least, thereâ€™s a lot of constraint and tension in my system. Part of this is what I was feeling in my neck. I sit at the computer and I hold myself still. I sit and I pay deep attention to people. To some degree, this feels good, but to another degree, itâ€™s like I don't need to hold myself that way to do what I want to do. I could move around, I could flow a lot more, but I seem to have lost that ability, that habit. It almost makes me feel disembodied or artificial.During the trip, I could feel myself move around. I thought, â€œMan, I'm just so locked up in myself. I need to relax and to move more.â€I had a couple of other experiences, including one that felt like it completely rewired my nervous system for a minute (my bodily sense became hypersuggestible and I â€œfeltâ€ the texture of my Cookie Monster fleece pullover in my body every time it entered my vision), and another one in which some deep lore that I had completely forgotten about got stirred up (still processing that childhood stuff). I think I need more time for those. I may write about them in the future. text_content: OverviewWe dive into the nature of prediction, culture wars, and human freedom in this unscripted conversation between three friends exploring ideas at the intersection of technology, philosophy, and memetics. Starting with the question â€œis this a podcast or just a call?â€ we unpack why perfect prediction might be dangerous, how cultures survive or die, and what it means to be truly free in an interconnected world.The conversation centers around a fundamental tension: as we get better at predicting the future, do we increase our agency or lock ourselves into predetermined paths? Through discussions of reflexivity, culture wars as humanityâ€™s way of understanding itself, and the difference between external prediction and internal authenticity, we explore what values actually matter when building tools and systems that shape human behavior.We covered a lot of ground today!

We open with meta-commentary about the format itself - Omar (as DefenderOfBasic) explains how these recorded conversations help him articulate what he does, while Caleb represents the â€œmemetically neutralâ€ position of creating without publishing. Sets the tone for transparency and thinking out loud.

Omar shows his Twitter visualization where tweets cluster by semantic similarity, proposing each thought as a neuron firing in humanityâ€™s collective brain. We discuss how ideas propagate and connect across the social graph.

The question of when to be fully transparent online - Omar contemplates using both identities for different purposes, with Defender as the unfiltered experimental space and Omar as the â€œseriousâ€ persona. Caleb suggests Defender handles what can't be fully transparent.

13:00 - Culture Wars as Natural Selection

Omar argues culture wars are â€œthe most important thing in the worldâ€ - not about ideology but about which behavioral patterns survive. We explore how cultures with certain features (like having children) propagate while others naturally die out. The dark implication: some worldviews are literally unsustainable.

text_content: What defines the â€œtpotâ€ Twitter sphere? We identify the pattern of public self-exploration and real-time processing of growth. Discussion of whether constant internal focus helps incubation or becomes limiting - when do you need to look outward again?The oft-used, consensus resistant label for everyoneâ€™s personal Twitter projection space. What is tpot? Your guess is as good as mind. But, it probably includes some element of authentic interpersonal wayfinding.26:00 - The Taurus Prediction Market DebateThe core question emerges through a concrete example: Taurus, a system that retroactively rewards correct predictions. Omarâ€™s friend claims it will â€œfix everythingâ€ while another warns it will destroy everything through reflexivity. This launches our deep dive into prediction and free will.Mechanically improving market efficiency considered harmful.32:30 - Perfect Prediction and the Loss of Free WillUsing graphs showing fitted curves through data points, we explore how perfect prediction could eliminate the gap where free will exists. The more accurately we predict, the more we might lock ourselves into specific futures, losing the expansiveness that makes us human.Taijitu Observer explains how our predictions might actually make us worse at connection and understanding the world.37:00 - Reality Always Breaks ModelsWe establish that perfect prediction is impossible because reality is always larger than our models. Even irrelevant-seeming data eventually affects long-term predictions. This structural impossibility preserves human agency.

text_content: Iâ€™m struggling to figure out how to tell this story. It has a lot of sensitive, uh, topics, which I am happy to tell, but not happy to publish on the open internet. Context is king. Nothing bad, but just... salacious. I will do my best to convey the truth of the experience without delving into the explicit or uncouth.Iâ€™ve dated pretty â€œhardâ€ since my divorce. Iâ€™ve clocked three serious relationships since then, and one of them actually had a â€œPart II: Electric Boogalooâ€ reprisal. Each one took a serious toll. text_content: My love was not her. It was never her. It was this life. It was always this immediate, intimate, sensory experience. The way beauty finds a seat on every perch, among every pile of clothes, of hair, of twisting cords and cables, of memory cards splayed amongst each other in a little case on my desk. The wild wiles of this aesthetic existence, unifying this untamed universe anew in each moment, each beat... this is my True Love.Gobbsmacked, I sputtered and stammered my way through a voice note, trying to capture the essence of what had revealed itself in me in that moment.And Iâ€™m just like, man, I want to get beautiful. Part of me wants to be really beautiful. I just likeâ€”my body is art, how I love is art, how I kiss, how I fuck is art, and I just want it, I want to honor that. Itâ€™s like I want to get fit. I want to get beautiful. I want to take care of myself. Itâ€™s just, there is nothing in my life that is not artistic, that doesnâ€™t have an aesthetic essence. And I just want to honor all of it.Like, Iâ€™m just being overcome with the desire to find the art and beauty and the intricacies. And I justâ€”itâ€™s consuming me. Itâ€™s like, fuck, what am I living for if Iâ€™m not living for art? Like, science is great, and thereâ€™s art in science, but like the beauty of the senses, theâ€”theâ€”the tantalizing delicacy that is sensory awareness andâ€”and feedback mechanisms and so itâ€™s justâ€”why would I live if I'm not living in this essence, living for this, with this? I canâ€™t fathom it, honestly.

text_content: OverviewIn this sprawling conversation, Defender and I explore the architecture of belief systems, cultural transmission, and the mechanics of how ideas spread through society. We dive deep into Defender's dual identity experiment (Omar the scientist vs Defender the mystic), discuss why fact-checkers might make us dumber, and unpack how the human superorganism is still in its infancy. The conversation weaves through practical questions about organizing research, the value of sincerity in communication, and why changing someone's mind requires becoming vulnerable to having your own mind changed.
html_content:
Overview

In this sprawling conversation, Defender and I explore the architecture of belief systems, cultural transmission, and the mechanics of how ideas spread through society. We dive deep into Defender's dual identity experiment (Omar the scientist vs Defender the mystic), discuss why fact-checkers might make us dumber, and unpack how the human superorganism is still in its infancy. The conversation weaves through practical questions about organizing research, the value of sincerity in communication, and why changing someone's mind requires becoming vulnerable to having your own mind changed.

heading: Overview

text_content: Chapters & Key Points[00:00:00] The Never-Ending Newsletter ProblemDefender struggles with creating ORI updates because new developments keep happening faster than he can document themWe discuss how knowledge storage in people (live, updated) differs from storage in books (fossilized)The real value isn't capturing everything but creating canonical reference points that can be retired once they become common knowledgeThe ORI newsletter, where Defender catalogues the strides of the ORI egregore.[00:07:17] Scientific Paradigms & Cultural KnowledgeMost working scientists don't understand how scientific paradigms actually functionKnowledge exists both in individual minds and embedded in cultural patternsWe follow behavioral patterns without knowing why - the knowledge is stored in the culture itself[00:10:33] Subjective Science & Being Your Own Research SubjectMichael Smith's concept that you must become both researcher and subjectORI's frontier work involves "debugging" self-reinforcing cultural loopsThe challenge of analyzing systems you're embedded withinSubjective science means taking yourself as the test subject and running experiments on your own experience.[00:23:03] The Omar/Defender Split Brain ExperimentDefender reveals his dual identity: Omar (rational computer graphics engineer) vs Defender (mystic)Different epistemologies require different voices - some truths can't be communicated rationallyThe strategic value of maintaining separate identities for reaching different audiences
html_content:
Chapters & Key Points

[00:00:00] The Never-Ending Newsletter Problem

  • Defender struggles with creating ORI updates because new developments keep happening faster than he can document them

  • We discuss how knowledge storage in people (live, updated) differs from storage in books (fossilized)

  • The real value isn't capturing everything but creating canonical reference points that can be retired once they become common knowledge

[00:07:17] Scientific Paradigms & Cultural Knowledge

  • Most working scientists don't understand how scientific paradigms actually function

  • Knowledge exists both in individual minds and embedded in cultural patterns

  • We follow behavioral patterns without knowing why - the knowledge is stored in the culture itself

[00:10:33] Subjective Science & Being Your Own Research Subject

  • Michael Smith's concept that you must become both researcher and subject

  • ORI's frontier work involves "debugging" self-reinforcing cultural loops

  • The challenge of analyzing systems you're embedded within

[00:23:03] The Omar/Defender Split Brain Experiment

  • Defender reveals his dual identity: Omar (rational computer graphics engineer) vs Defender (mystic)

  • Different epistemologies require different voices - some truths can't be communicated rationally

  • The strategic value of maintaining separate identities for reaching different audiences

text_content: Defender vs his â€œalterâ€ ego, whose public personas each represent two sides of the same coin.[00:29:03] Surface vs Solve: Why Fact-Checkers Make Us DumberFact-checkers that you don't understand make you more vulnerable to manipulation"Surface" approach: expose people to information and let them develop antibodiesThe driving metaphor: blind spot sensors help you learn vs self-driving cars that remove agencyDefenderâ€™s surfacing of the idea of â€œsurface vs solve.â€[00:38:56] Open Memetics & The Propaganda Rating SystemVision for a system where anyone can bring information to be ratedThree responses: "This is frontier knowledge," "This is N weeks old," or "This is propaganda"Every interaction becomes a teaching moment - even identifying propaganda builds skillsThe draft ORI mystic peer review rubric that we devised together.[00:50:19] Mapping Twitter's Hidden NetworksDefender describes deliberately tweeting to different clusters (tech bros, artists, Muslims)Creating "razors" - tweets that unite disparate groups by hitting shared blind spotsUsing people's reactions as a distributed intelligence system to map cultural terrainDefender described strategies for mapping and understanding different social clusters, including the overlaps between them.[01:06:31] "Would You Even Know If It Was True?"The defensive mechanisms that prevent us from examining load-bearing beliefsHow belief change happens constantly but we don't track itThe hostility of forcing truth on people who haven't invited you in
html_content:
[00:29:03] Surface vs Solve: Why Fact-Checkers Make Us Dumber

  • Fact-checkers that you don't understand make you more vulnerable to manipulation

  • "Surface" approach: expose people to information and let them develop antibodies

  • The driving metaphor: blind spot sensors help you learn vs self-driving cars that remove agency

[00:38:56] Open Memetics & The Propaganda Rating System

  • Vision for a system where anyone can bring information to be rated

  • Three responses: "This is frontier knowledge," "This is N weeks old," or "This is propaganda"

  • Every interaction becomes a teaching moment - even identifying propaganda builds skills

[00:50:19] Mapping Twitter's Hidden Networks

  • Defender describes deliberately tweeting to different clusters (tech bros, artists, Muslims)

  • Creating "razors" - tweets that unite disparate groups by hitting shared blind spots

  • Using people's reactions as a distributed intelligence system to map cultural terrain

[01:06:31] "Would You Even Know If It Was True?"

  • The defensive mechanisms that prevent us from examining load-bearing beliefs

  • How belief change happens constantly but we don't track it

  • The hostility of forcing truth on people who haven't invited you in

text_content: There are many approaches to synchronizing and updating shared beliefs (culture), and some approaches lend themselves to better norms of collaboration than others.[01:12:46] Integration Through Contact, Not ConversionYou can't change beliefs by attacking them directlyBridge-building between groups leads to natural belief evolutionThe joy is in the friction and engagement, not in achieving uniformityYou donâ€™t have to try to change beliefs. Just open yourself up to being changed, and interact earnestly and honestly. The integration happens between the two of youâ€¦ as long as they do, too.[01:26:17] Groups as Simplified Models of Individual MindsGroup dynamics are like studying psychology in slow motionThe human superorganism is immature because our connection bandwidth is lowMemetics in groups follows simpler, more observable patterns than individual thoughtThe human superorganism is still gestating. Because itâ€™s still relatively simple, we can derive insights about the human mind by examining how they interact in well-mapped group dynamics (in the superorganism).[01:29:51] The Frontier Is Empty (Justin Sledge Example)Professor teaching YouTube course on topic with no existing accessible bookMost frontiers have only 5 people attempting them, not millions competingThe path to contribution: document what experts are teaching as you learnJustin Sledge is an example of someone clearing a space near a longstanding frontier by creating a YouTube lecture series that more closely examines ancient traditions.[01:33:21] Finding Your Unique Frontier vs Simulating Feynman
html_content:
[01:12:46] Integration Through Contact, Not Conversion

  • You can't change beliefs by attacking them directly

  • Bridge-building between groups leads to natural belief evolution

  • The joy is in the friction and engagement, not in achieving uniformity

[01:26:17] Groups as Simplified Models of Individual Minds

  • Group dynamics are like studying psychology in slow motion

  • The human superorganism is immature because our connection bandwidth is low

  • Memetics in groups follows simpler, more observable patterns than individual thought

[01:29:51] The Frontier Is Empty (Justin Sledge Example)

  • Professor teaching YouTube course on topic with no existing accessible book

  • Most frontiers have only 5 people attempting them, not millions competing

  • The path to contribution: document what experts are teaching as you learn

text_content: Okay.This is going to be the last LLM-generated text that I post here. The end of an era, albeit a short-lived one. Part of the motivation to post this stuff was not to share the content so much as to show off what is possible with LLMs, currently. The last couple of entries I posted were driven by this aim, including one where I clearly laid out the process and invited you, the reader, to ask for help in trying it out, if you wanted.I truly believe in the value of this, and Iâ€™m using it every other day to work through subtle little conditioning in a gentle, mind-led way. It really helps. It doesnâ€™t replace therapy, but if all you need is the space to find coherence, it may be good enough for prime time.As I documented in the last post, this can be a great tool for finding existential peace and relational courage alike.So, that brings me to this post. As I like to do, I followed my normal process:I consumed some content (a Vsauce video, in this case, spurred on by Defenderâ€™s latest post, which you should totally read, btw)I ranted into a voice note for ~5 minutesI transcribed the note and dropped it into Claude Opus 4.1, and asked it to dissect the concept with meI asked for an â€œExpressionâ€ at the end, with a specific prompt (reproduced below)I like to set the stage before I get into it. It tends to prime the LLM to be more exploratory and creative.
html_content:
Okay.

This is going to be the last LLM-generated text that I post here. The end of an era, albeit a short-lived one. Part of the motivation to post this stuff was not to share the content so much as to show off what is possible with LLMs, currently. The last couple of entries I posted were driven by this aim, including one where I clearly laid out the process and invited you, the reader, to ask for help in trying it out, if you wanted.

I truly believe in the value of this, and Iâ€™m using it every other day to work through subtle little conditioning in a gentle, mind-led way. It really helps. It doesnâ€™t replace therapy, but if all you need is the space to find coherence, it may be good enough for prime time.

So, that brings me to this post. As I like to do, I followed my normal process:

  1. I consumed some content (a Vsauce video, in this case, spurred on by Defenderâ€™s latest post, which you should totally read, btw)

  2. I ranted into a voice note for ~5 minutes

  3. I transcribed the note and dropped it into Claude Opus 4.1, and asked it to dissect the concept with me

  4. I asked for an â€œExpressionâ€ at the end, with a specific prompt (reproduced below)

text_content: The Joshua Paradox: An Odyssey Through Being and Not-BeingI was listening to Vsauce's latest video, "All the Ghosts You Will Be," watching him stab a knife theatrically into a flour container, letting a few grains fall onto black paper. "This is the people that you will ever meet," he said. "You're a stranger to your own race, and yet the ghosts are getting closer." And I thought: what an interesting way to frame what might be a mistaken tragedy.
