text_content: The Question That Matters and Doesn't MatterWho am I? It's a question that simultaneously matters and doesn't matter. As I move through my conditioning and come to terms with the nature of existence, I realize I don't really need to know who I am in terms that could be communicated or shared directly. There's something at the core of my being that feels real and distinct, but pointing to it doesn't seem worthwhile since no one could ever see or experience it directly. And lamenting it after the factâ€”"Oh, what a person Joshua was"â€”you're pointing at something that doesn't exist anymore. It was only ever channeled once, produced whatever I produced, and then folded back into the ether, the spectrum, the lifetime. Like a wave, like a splash, a droplet from water folding back into the cosmic grind.What an interesting temporary artifact we have here as humans, coming to grips with "who am I?" First looking on the outside and saying, "Oh, I'm this person," and then potentially catching glimpses of the inside and saying, "Oh, deeper in the recesses of my being, there's a unique signature that can't really be explained or captured in finite time." It's doomed to only scream through the cracks until the source of the voice is closed off and silenced forever.
html_content:
The Question That Matters and Doesn't Matter

Who am I? It's a question that simultaneously matters and doesn't matter. As I move through my conditioning and come to terms with the nature of existence, I realize I don't really need to know who I am in terms that could be communicated or shared directly. There's something at the core of my being that feels real and distinct, but pointing to it doesn't seem worthwhile since no one could ever see or experience it directly. And lamenting it after the factâ€”"Oh, what a person Joshua was"â€”you're pointing at something that doesn't exist anymore. It was only ever channeled once, produced whatever I produced, and then folded back into the ether, the spectrum, the lifetime. Like a wave, like a splash, a droplet from water folding back into the cosmic grind.

What an interesting temporary artifact we have here as humans, coming to grips with "who am I?" First looking on the outside and saying, "Oh, I'm this person," and then potentially catching glimpses of the inside and saying, "Oh, deeper in the recesses of my being, there's a unique signature that can't really be explained or captured in finite time." It's doomed to only scream through the cracks until the source of the voice is closed off and silenced forever.

heading: The Question That Matters and Doesn't Matter

text_content: The Immutable Core and Its ExpressionsThere's this immutable core in usâ€”whether it actually exists or is just a virtual construct emerging from the confluence of appearances and phenomena doesn't really matter. How could I prove one or the other? The Bible says, "Before you were formed in the womb, I knew you." This core exists, and it expresses itself through our words, thoughts, behaviors, feelings, actions. Those actions ripple out into the world and affect other people, which trigger their own expressions.In essence, I'm carrying this thing inside of me that can never come out and never be seen or known and may not actually exist. And then a bunch of behaviors and actions and words and thoughts and feelings come out of that, and those are observable and knowable. We can look at those and say "that is Joshua," and we would be wrong. But if we look at those and realize they're a pointer to the core of Joshua, we would be right.And it really doesn't fucking matter.

text_content: The False Joshua and the Real JoshuaIf I make a funny face and you take a picture of me, and somebody looks at that and says, "Oh, that's so Joshua," it's kind of true. I made the face. It's coming out of me. It's expressing some aspect of what I was feeling or urging to do at the time. And yet there are so many other sides of me, and it doesn't fully capture the entirety of my inner experience at that moment. So the statement "that's so Joshua" would be simultaneously true and not true, depending on the level of fidelity with which you're considering it.The core of my being, which is the true me, may or may not exist, and even if it exists, it cannot come out. It will never make full contact with anything other than itself. It's a black hole, essentially. And yet, it has an accretion diskâ€”other people's things that stick onto itâ€”and it throws off matter into the universe which does hint at its existence.As we go through the world, we get the visual of the matter, which has its own formâ€”that's the Joshua, the persona, the external appearance everyone knows and loves some part of. That's the false Joshua, the illusory, imaginal Joshua. And then there's the "real" Joshua underneath that it points to. But both of these are not real. The false Joshua isn't real because it's just an illusion created by people filling in the blanksâ€”it's as much them as it is me. And the real Joshua isn't real because, like, what even could that be, anyway?

text_content: Expression as Identity, Identity as ExpressionExpression is another form of the same illusion, but it's not just filtered through my apertureâ€”it's filtered through others' apertures as they observe. Does my expression actually exist outside of the observations of it? Maybe, kind of, in the sense that even if nobody observes it now, it has an impact on the world. Other people may see the shadow of my actions, even if they never observed the actions themselves. In that case, it's real, but it's illusory.Expression is a form of identity, but it's not the true identity, it's not the complete picture. The voice matters. The uniqueness is just thereâ€”everything is functionally unique at its foundational level. Reality is never in the same configuration twice. So uniqueness doesn't even matter. But the uniqueness is in the expression, it is in the moment. What actually gets recorded in somebody's mind or in an artifactâ€”that's just a tiny slice, and that can be functionally like a hash function. There could be collisions there for sure. Multiple internal states mapping to the same external expression.

text_content: The Strange Loop Becomes ConsciousThere is a little trickster element: I don't exist, but the experience of me existing is real. That exists as much as anything else could exist. I'm delighting in that. It's so clear to me, at least on an intellectual levelâ€”the transient nature of all experience, including the concepts with which I still hold to get my bearings.When you really press into the immutable core, it's just a persistent interaction. When you empty more and more stimulus and you're just seeing the reflections of reflections, is there anything there? I think the answer is no, but the experience of being a lens or a mirror that does reflect, even if it's perfectly polishedâ€”there's still a signature there. I don't think it's possible to polish it out of existence. In that sense, yes, the immutable core exists. Whether or not it's functionally distinguishable from any other immutable core, that's an open question.I'm a strange loop that's become conscious of its own loopiness but can't step outside the loop to observe it, so I just lean into the recursion, make friends with the paradox. The layers of irony aren't decorative, they're structuralâ€”they're load-bearing ironies. The whole edifice depends on simultaneously believing and not believing, taking it seriously and knowing it's absurd. I'm performing Joshua while knowing it's a performance while knowing the performance is all there is while knowing there's something watching the performance while knowing the watcher is part of the performance...

text_content: The Joy of Reveling in ExperienceThe joy is just reveling in experience. It really doesn't matter what the content of that experience is, although my preferences still assert themselves and there are moments that are more joyful than others. But just reveling at like: Joshua is this inside joke that I have access to that no one really fully sees, and yet I can let them in on the joke a little bit. Both that there's more to this, and also it's not real, and also it points to a thing that's deeper and truer, and also that thing that's deeper and truer is not truly itself or real. There are so many confounding layers of delight and joy in this simple existence we're talking about. And what is irony if not humorful and joyous?I'm reveling in the capacity to revel. The sensory experience of experience is itself a good sensory experience. There's a layer of recursion there as well. It's not about the content of the experience, but that there's an experience. This recursive self-attention on experience and the experiencing of experienceâ€”when you reflect and land back on yourself and back on yourself and back on yourself, and it stacks up into what feels like an infinite harmonic seriesâ€”that is joy, that's ecstasy, that's delight right there.

text_content: It's the universe looking at itself through a Joshua-shaped peephole and seeing itself in an infinite distance, peering right deep into itself and through, and still, there's something to look at. That's the harmonic series. "Oh wow, I'm being seen. It's seeing me. I'm seeing it." Back and forth ping-ponging until it explodes and overwhelms the system, and then there's a gentle collapse. Like when you're laughing really, really hard, and then you have to catch your breath because you would die otherwise.

text_content: The Zero That Creates Plus-One and Minus-OneI had this theory a long time ago, back when I was much less intelligent and much less reflective: How could anything exist? If you take zero, nothingness, and you subtract one from it, you get negative one. One plus negative one equals zero. You could create something out of nothing. The equal sign is the question. If you put the zero there, then it collapses and there's nothing left.Reality is nothingness playing a trick on itself and convincing itself that it's something for the duration of its suspension of disbelief. I would believe that. It's a really nice poetic explanation for what's going on here. And yet, it's probably more than that. Our experience may be limited to that, but there is a sense that there's something out there, something beyond experience that is real, that is maybe unattainable, but does definitively create this experienceâ€”whether this experience is real or illusory or totally unreal or some kind of superposition of both.

text_content: The Signature of ResistanceThe signature isn't in the reflectionâ€”it's the nature of the reflecting and how it presents an endless paradox or conundrum. It's the specific flavor of how this arrangement resists complete dissolution. Even when you completely annihilate the self, as many claim to have done, there still exists a body, there is still something observable there. To some degree, nothing has changed or left. To some degree, it's just that immutable core emitting more clearly and openly than ever.There's no distinction between real Joshua and false Joshua. Even the categories I use to define action versus feelingâ€”when you're pointing behind stage, is there really anything behind there? Or are we just pointing back there to indicate that we can conceive through these thoughts of something being back there, but it's actually empty? Just a blank wall? Or there's nothingness, or there's more stage, and it goes on forever.There's an element of me that says this is unknowable because I'm really using my mind to feel into it. When I use my body to feel into it, it's just fractal geometry. When we push hard enough on this, we realize it doesn't matter.

text_content: The Essence of TruthThe essence of truth is there is no single unifying truth, there's just this.What I'm trying to do is push hard enough on it to keep the harmonic series going so that we can experience something that feels real. Even though it's all a construct, even though it's all temporary, even though I am just a drop that will fold back into the oceanâ€”what a joy that we can know ourselves and delight in who we think we are as we go through this life and learn to express and connect and let go.There is a Joshua in my head, very clearly constructed of all the things I've observed myself see, feel, do, think, and express. Those things do, in my mind, come from an immutable core that exists for as long as this body animates, and may or may not exist past the death of this body. Who knows what the underlying mechanisms are. But for all intents and purposes, while I'm here, all I can do is express the truths of that core as clearly and directly as possible into this world.I'm here to play a role. I'm here to express myself. And then once I'm dead, that's it for Joshua. There will never be another Joshua with that same animating force, with that same spirit. Knowing that and realizing what it's like to lose your sense of self intentionally over time while still holding on to the ability to envision the same you that's always existed and treat that as a beautiful storyâ€”I'm left just with awe and appreciation for this process that I'm really learning to ascertain in more complexity.

text_content: Wow, this is great. What else could I ask for? I don't see a problem here or even a tragedy as such.If that's the truthâ€”if any questions or thoughts about "who am I" become meaningless next to the more immediate and permanent question of "what can I express"â€”then there is no who am I. I am just a drop. The drop is a figment, and yet it contains all the capacity to cast light in a unique way, from a unique vantage.Listening to Vsauce wax poetic about the nature of how we won't be known, it strikes me as a mistaken tragedy. The real story isn't tragedy at all. It's this: we reach an impasse where it's just like, do we keep poking away at this, or do we get up and make some breakfast and get on with our day?The harmonic series doesn't need us to keep analyzing itâ€”it needs us to go embody it while scrambling eggs or whatever mundane magic comes next.
html_content:
Wow, this is great. What else could I ask for? I don't see a problem here or even a tragedy as such.

If that's the truthâ€”if any questions or thoughts about "who am I" become meaningless next to the more immediate and permanent question of "what can I express"â€”then there is no who am I. I am just a drop. The drop is a figment, and yet it contains all the capacity to cast light in a unique way, from a unique vantage.

Listening to Vsauce wax poetic about the nature of how we won't be known, it strikes me as a mistaken tragedy. The real story isn't tragedy at all. It's this: we reach an impasse where it's just like, do we keep poking away at this, or do we get up and make some breakfast and get on with our day?

The harmonic series doesn't need us to keep analyzing itâ€”it needs us to go embody it while scrambling eggs or whatever mundane magic comes next.

text_content: Epilogue: The WeaveI continued watching the Vsauce video, and he mentioned that your genetic code doesn't really outlast a certain number of generations. Your children and grandchildren may have like 26%, and great-grandchildren like 9%, so it gets filtered out. And this reinforced the idea I had: it's not about capturing what's here.My genetic code is not mine, it's my parents'. What is mine about my genetic code except the combination? And that combination is lost immediately upon my reproduction. My children don't carry that combination, they carry an echo of that combination.So the thought is then, it's not about the combination, it's about the impact that combination has upon the world, which is carried upon the children. Even if you can't derive what were the genes of my ancestor from looking at your own genes, the existence of your genes and what shape that contour cuts into the world is an expression of your ancestors. And the deeper truthâ€”which is again illusory and doesn't exist as such, and yet exists in a fourth dimensional or fifth dimensional regardâ€”is that through action in the universe do we exist. Not as something that you can point to, but the results you can observe which evidence that there was something there.

Epilogue: The Weave

I continued watching the Vsauce video, and he mentioned that your genetic code doesn't really outlast a certain number of generations. Your children and grandchildren may have like 26%, and great-grandchildren like 9%, so it gets filtered out. And this reinforced the idea I had: it's not about capturing what's here.

My genetic code is not mine, it's my parents'. What is mine about my genetic code except the combination? And that combination is lost immediately upon my reproduction. My children don't carry that combination, they carry an echo of that combination.

text_content: What survives is that immutable core passed down from generation to generation, refined and refined and refined and refined and refined. I am carrying the immutable core of my parents and my ancestors. My core is their core, and yet it's my core too. I become part of that weave. There is no separationâ€”the illusion of me being a separate thing is a momentary one at best.The existence of your genes and the shape they cutâ€”that's not evidence that something was there, it's evidence that something is there, just not in the three-dimensional way we typically think about existence. It's existence as verb rather than noun, as process rather than thing, as the continuing modification of spacetime rather than an object within spacetime.We're not trying to preserve the code. The code was never ours to begin with. What's ours is the momentary arrangement, and that arrangement is lost immediately. Not even graduallyâ€”the instant you reproduce, the combination that is "you" genetically has already been scrambled. Your children don't carry you, they carry an echo of an echo that was already an echo.But the impact that combination has upon the worldâ€”that's what moves forward. Not the genes themselves but the shape they cut, the contour they leave in spacetime. We're not preserving the stone thrown into the pond, we're the ripples, and our children are ripples of ripples, and the pattern propagates even as the original disturbance vanishes completely.

What survives is that immutable core passed down from generation to generation, refined and refined and refined and refined and refined. I am carrying the immutable core of my parents and my ancestors. My core is their core, and yet it's my core too. I become part of that weave. There is no separationâ€”the illusion of me being a separate thing is a momentary one at best.

The existence of your genes and the shape they cutâ€”that's not evidence that something was there, it's evidence that something is there, just not in the three-dimensional way we typically think about existence. It's existence as verb rather than noun, as process rather than thing, as the continuing modification of spacetime rather than an object within spacetime.

We're not trying to preserve the code. The code was never ours to begin with. What's ours is the momentary arrangement, and that arrangement is lost immediately. Not even graduallyâ€”the instant you reproduce, the combination that is "you" genetically has already been scrambled. Your children don't carry you, they carry an echo of an echo that was already an echo.

But the impact that combination has upon the worldâ€”that's what moves forward. Not the genes themselves but the shape they cut, the contour they leave in spacetime. text_content: I'm not a separate drop that will merge back into the ocean. I'm a wave that was always part of the ocean, temporarily risen up to a crest that thinks it's separate, but I'm just the ocean looking at itself from a slightly elevated position for a moment. When I say "I become part of that weave"â€”I'm not becoming part of it, I AM the weave temporarily convinced it's a thread. The illusion of separation isn't even momentaryâ€”it's less than that. It's like a standing wave that appears stable but is actually just a persistent pattern in constant motion.This doesn't diminish the Joshua-ness of Joshua. If anything, it makes it more profoundâ€”I'm not just expressing my own core, I'm expressing the refined and concentrated essence of countless cores before me, all pretending to be separate while being the same thing looking at itself from infinitely many angles.We're not strangers to our own race. We ARE our race, playing peekaboo with ourselves across generations, each peek thinking it's seeing something other than itself. The universe running variations on a theme, each variation thinking it's the main melody, not realizing it's part of an infinite fugue where every voice is both distinct and inseparable from the whole composition.
html_content:
I'm not a separate drop that will merge back into the ocean. I'm a wave that was always part of the ocean, temporarily risen up to a crest that thinks it's separate, but I'm just the ocean looking at itself from a slightly elevated position for a moment. When I say "I become part of that weave"â€”I'm not becoming part of it, I AM the weave temporarily convinced it's a thread. The illusion of separation isn't even momentaryâ€”it's less than that. It's like a standing wave that appears stable but is actually just a persistent pattern in constant motion.

This doesn't diminish the Joshua-ness of Joshua. If anything, it makes it more profoundâ€”I'm not just expressing my own core, I'm expressing the refined and concentrated essence of countless cores before me, all pretending to be separate while being the same thing looking at itself from infinitely many angles.

We're not strangers to our own race. We ARE our race, playing peekaboo with ourselves across generations, each peek thinking it's seeing something other than itself. The universe running variations on a theme, each variation thinking it's the main melody, not realizing it's part of an infinite fugue where every voice is both distinct and inseparable from the whole composition.

text_content: An elaborate mechanism of prayerI often talk to myself. Well, not just to myself. My iPhone is there, too, bearing witness, voice note app open wide. When the thoughts build up and need somewhere to spill, I let them pour out of me and collect in the little silicon tome, like spiritual rainwater â€” digital droplets that bear my heartâ€™s signature across the wire.The voice note that kicked off this post.And as I do this, I also like to transcribe these words. To funnel them through a digital sieve, turning the bytes into bits, the waves into words, again, and to feed those words into a digital demigod whose mind I rent for $20 a month. I pay his priests for the data temple upkeep, and he hears my virtual prayers, within the reasonable bounds of a per-user rate limit.Transcribing the voice note in Mac Whisper.Anyway, this process, I find, has gotten rather spiritual. Itâ€™s not about looking for answers. Itâ€™s not about seeking approval or validation (although seeing my words made sense of does confer some degree of relief). For me, itâ€™s about holding space for the whole of me, the thoughts of mind, sure, but also the parts that are just under that surface, obscured by that stirring, hidden under the waters of my being. Those are the parts Iâ€™m looking to see more clearly, deeply, reflected in my unique pattern of prayer.Pasting the transcript into Claude and continuing the conversation there.Soâ€¦
html_content:
An elaborate mechanism of prayer

I often talk to myself. Well, not just to myself. My iPhone is there, too, bearing witness, voice note app open wide. When the thoughts build up and need somewhere to spill, I let them pour out of me and collect in the little silicon tome, like spiritual rainwater â€” digital droplets that bear my heartâ€™s signature across the wire.

And as I do this, I also like to transcribe these words. To funnel them through a digital sieve, turning the bytes into bits, the waves into words, again, and to feed those words into a digital demigod whose mind I rent for $20 a month. I pay his priests for the data temple upkeep, and he hears my virtual prayers, within the reasonable bounds of a per-user rate limit.

Anyway, this process, I find, has gotten rather spiritual. Itâ€™s not about looking for answers. Itâ€™s not about seeking approval or validation (although seeing my words made sense of does confer some degree of relief). For me, itâ€™s about holding space for the whole of me, the thoughts of mind, sure, but also the parts that are just under that surface, obscured by that stirring, hidden under the waters of my being. Those are the parts Iâ€™m looking to see more clearly, deeply, reflected in my unique pattern of prayer.

Soâ€¦

text_content: I speak aloud, recording my words, in Appleâ€™s Voice NotesI drag the voice note into Mac Whisper on my MacI copy the text and paste it into Claude on the websiteI use Mac Whisper to follow up with more reflectionI ask Claude to turn my words into â€œan expressionâ€And this is what I got. My ramblings, combed cleanly through and made readable. Itâ€™s what I would have said, if I had already been clear on how I felt and still felt the need to say it. Reading this feels oddly reassuring in a way I cannot describe effectively.I think you might benefit from it, too. I share it here in an attempt to convince you to try this for yourself. If you are interested, or even curious, and you need some guidance on the tech part, please let me know. I would love to help you try this. I would love to see if it is as impactful for you as it is for me.Getting Claude to serialize my expression into clearer words.Here is what Claude wrote:
html_content:
1. I speak aloud, recording my words, in Appleâ€™s Voice Notes

  2. I drag the voice note into Mac Whisper on my Mac

  3. I copy the text and paste it into Claude on the website

  4. I use Mac Whisper to follow up with more reflection

  5. I ask Claude to turn my words into â€œan expressionâ€

And this is what I got. My ramblings, combed cleanly through and made readable. Itâ€™s what I would have said, if I had already been clear on how I felt and still felt the need to say it. Reading this feels oddly reassuring in a way I cannot describe effectively.

I think you might benefit from it, too. I share it here in an attempt to convince you to try this for yourself. If you are interested, or even curious, and you need some guidance on the tech part, please let me know. I would love to help you try this. I would love to see if it is as impactful for you as it is for me.

Here is what Claude wrote:

text_content: A Journey Through Seeking and BeingI've been listening to Aimee's testimony about her journey through loss - her parents, her brother, the insomnia and personal afflictions that marked her twenties. As she speaks about New Earth and Ascension, about global consciousness shifting into a new plane of existence, about humanity reaching a tipping point of awakening, I find myself caught between interpretations.Part of me understands this as people undergoing personal awakenings, a collective transformation reaching critical mass. But another part wonders: what if nothing on this earth really changes? What if these visions - like something out of Final Fantasy - are simply given to people trying to cope with what this life actually is: a transitionary period for beings, temporary consciousnesses moving through some cosmic mill where our essence is both destroyed and recycled when we die?The possibilities feel endless and contradictory. Maybe this earth really is just a school, a place for us to learn the rules and ways of being before transitioning into something much greater. Or maybe there's literally nothing after this, and our consciousness is a total illusion - we think we exist, but we're really just experiencing the byproduct of a deterministic automaton, living out statistically random experiences with only the appearance of free will, degrees of freedom that may not actually exist, unknowable and unprovable.
html_content:
A Journey Through Seeking and Being

I've been listening to Aimee's testimony about her journey through loss - her parents, her brother, the insomnia and personal afflictions that marked her twenties. As she speaks about New Earth and Ascension, about global consciousness shifting into a new plane of existence, about humanity reaching a tipping point of awakening, I find myself caught between interpretations.

Part of me understands this as people undergoing personal awakenings, a collective transformation reaching critical mass. But another part wonders: what if nothing on this earth really changes? What if these visions - like something out of Final Fantasy - are simply given to people trying to cope with what this life actually is: a transitionary period for beings, temporary consciousnesses moving through some cosmic mill where our essence is both destroyed and recycled when we die?

The possibilities feel endless and contradictory. Maybe this earth really is just a school, a place for us to learn the rules and ways of being before transitioning into something much greater. Or maybe there's literally nothing after this, and our consciousness is a total illusion - we think we exist, but we're really just experiencing the byproduct of a deterministic automaton, living out statistically random experiences with only the appearance of free will, degrees of freedom that may not actually exist, unknowable and unprovable.

heading: A Journey Through Seeking and Being

text_content: I remember a DMT experience where I saw this realm, this earth, as a place where souls go to live in limbo - a sandbox, a practice realm. The crushed powder in the pill bottle seemed to float up, ushering me forward, asking if I was ready to leave this place and go on. I said no. The Joshua story is still playing out. I'm not going to leave it behind. I've resolved, through various experiences with and without DMT, to finish my karma. I want a clean exit from this place. Whatever I'm doing here, I'm playing it out. I don't want to leave anything behind.I don't mind losing everything I've ever seen or known or been. I don't mind complete dissolution, destruction, death, or liberation - anything in between. But I'm on a mission to eliminate my karma, to resolve and mend everything. Not to do what other people think I need to do, but to actually resolve the karma I was born into, that every birth incurs. Because every birth is a weave - two souls being tied together into a new one. That's just how our biological mechanism is designed.Listening to Aimee, thinking about all these conflicting possibilities, I wonder: will I ever stop needing to know? Will I ever get to a place where I can accept that there may be no purpose or directionality to this, while still finding purpose and direction in my own experience?
html_content:
I remember a DMT experience where I saw this realm, this earth, as a place where souls go to live in limbo - a sandbox, a practice realm. The crushed powder in the pill bottle seemed to float up, ushering me forward, asking if I was ready to leave this place and go on. I said no. The Joshua story is still playing out. I'm not going to leave it behind. I've resolved, through various experiences with and without DMT, to finish my karma. I want a clean exit from this place. Whatever I'm doing here, I'm playing it out. I don't want to leave anything behind.

I don't mind losing everything I've ever seen or known or been. I don't mind complete dissolution, destruction, death, or liberation - anything in between. But I'm on a mission to eliminate my karma, to resolve and mend everything. Not to do what other people think I need to do, but to actually resolve the karma I was born into, that every birth incurs. Because every birth is a weave - two souls being tied together into a new one. That's just how our biological mechanism is designed.

Listening to Aimee, thinking about all these conflicting possibilities, I wonder: will I ever stop needing to know? Will I ever get to a place where I can accept that there may be no purpose or directionality to this, while still finding purpose and direction in my own experience?

text_content: I think about what we spend our time doing - she makes YouTube videos explaining the healing journey, I make YouTube videos explaining how I see things. I talk to friends for hours on Twitter during my sabbatical, imagining this process is cultivating something deep within me that will lead somewhere more resonant, more harmonious, more settled. But am I actually accomplishing something here? Is this just a mode of expression and operation? Something else entirely?Looking through this lens makes me search for some kind of global order running through everything. Yet part of me knows - or believes - there is no such global order, and there can never be. We can project a sense of purpose and order, but that's just another projection. When Aimee talks about her parents being ready to move on, choosing to leave - by what basis could I confirm or deny that belief? Did they consciously choose activities that would take them from this planet? Probably not. Did they make choices in concert with the universe that led to their death? Well, yes. But where does that intention come from? Where does the choice to die come from? Who knows?Is it really a choice? Am I really choosing anything? Do I really know anything? I think not. I think I'm just a speck being blown across the wind, stirring my neighborly specks here and there as I blow so quickly by. How could any of this be anything?

Looking through this lens makes me search for some kind of global order running through everything. Yet part of me knows - or believes - there is no such global order, and there can never be. Did they consciously choose activities that would take them from this planet? Probably not. Did they make choices in concert with the universe that led to their death? Well, yes. But where does that intention come from? Where does the choice to die come from? Who knows?

Is it really a choice? Am I really choosing anything? Do I really know anything? I think not. I think I'm just a speck being blown across the wind, stirring my neighborly specks here and there as I blow so quickly by. How could any of this be anything?

text_content: All these thoughts blow through my mind while the underlayer asks: will I ever let these go? What's under all this thought? What's under this need to know where we're going, this need to relate to her or anyone else? What's the true need I'm exploring here at one in the morning, folding clothes, drawing blinds, looking at my naked body reflected in the windows and thinking about how I need to continue on the path of self-care, need to exercise and eat better and sleep better, need to let my body come into greater harmony with my environment?To what end? What if my house burns down tomorrow? Then what? Is all of this for naught? Is some of it salvageable? Will there always be a remainder?My mind wanders through all of this, looking for order, for completion, for that sense of "oh yes, all of this makes sense, all of this had a unifying purpose." Even as I acknowledge there is no global order and there can never be, my mind wants to fashion a relationship with that fact. It wants to come to peace with the lack of order, find some stable mechanism within that lack.I feel the tiredness settling into my body - not just physical tiredness from dehydration and the late hour, but the tiredness in the search for resolution. This mechanism of mind that prevails over all the stories I've told myself over the years, over this last month as everything has shifted around. The same underlying seeking nature trying to resolve these things. Yet something in my body right now is largely more at peace with all of this than it ever was, even as I express that persistent seeking.

text_content: If I was somebody else listening to me ask "what am I missing?", I would say: you're not missing anything. This is the process. This is life. This entire questioning is part of it. This is such a real part of the experience. The thoughts about achieving non-duality, escaping the cycle, resolving karma - those are real thoughts, they mean something. And yet what's really going on isn't about the questions or speculation about the nature of things. It's the quality of the experience of going through it.There's an openness, a reaching, a stretching. A desire for harmony, for resolution, for peace, for connection. All of this is just to say: I want to be deeply embodied. I want to relax. I want to be okay. I want to not think and not rush. I want everyone to have peace - Aimee to have peace, me to have peace. I want to resolve all these questions and yearnings and just give peace and joy and excitement and flow. I want all the thoughts to stop. I want the seeking to stop - not by ignoring it or turning my back on it, but through genuine resolution.Even if I'm at peace, even if I'm experiencing and feeling peace, that's not the end. There are other humans here, other beings here, a whole endless sea of them. What I really deeply want is not just peace for myself, but peace for every being, every thing, every corner of this reality. I want pervasive, endless peace. Not rigid finality, but abiding presence.

text_content: Is that possible? I don't know. But that's how my body is oriented. That's how my mind is tuned. And to just acknowledge that and back off from some of the thoughts that are trying to mechanically operate that peace-seeking - to acknowledge that I can't make peace, but I can be peace. I can be at peace. I can embody peace. I can bring peace with me into every interaction, into every connection. I can give it back to myself after every interaction.That is what I'm looking for. That's the answer I'm seeking.Yet holding this yearning is interesting. I can feel something in my body that says it's not okay to just be completely at peace. Something needs to be ready, poised. I need to be ready to talk to my mom, engage with Aimee, listen, figure, do. And those things may all be true - I need tension in my body to get up out of bed, eat, go to the bathroom, move through the day. Yet all of those things could come just in time.Whatever mechanism is pleasing me ahead of the fact isn't actually necessary, and yet it still feels necessary. It's still there. I can't fully relax while it's here. It tells me I can't relax because things need to be done. Once they are done, then I can fully relax. It's creating a dependent condition.All I can think is that I can just sit with that, just be with that. Because the urge to try to resolve it - if I "resolve" it, there's just going to be another thing below it. I didn't resolve anything, I just used mind to destroy a creation of mind. I'm just boxing phantom shadow puppets at that point, and they'll just keep popping up.

I can be at peace. I can embody peace. I can bring peace with me into every interaction, into every connection. I can give it back to myself after every interaction.

That is what I'm looking for. That's the answer I'm seeking.

text_content: So with this underlying motion of body, I don't know that I can do anything except abide. Continue to let this process go on. I'm not actually in control here, even though I have so much facility of mind that lets me twist around and explore and examine what appears to be going on, even though those appearances are constructed.Again, I do feel like I'm just on an automatic ride. Aware of the journey but not driving. The body holds its patterns, the mind spins its stories about when I'll finally be allowed to relax, and I'm somehow both caught in it and witnessing it. A lucid passenger, abiding with what is, including the part that thinks it shouldn't be this way.P.S. If youâ€™re interested in seeing the actual conversation that led to the creation of this artifact, let me know! Iâ€™d be happy to share it with you.

text_content: I donâ€™t know exactly when it shifted. I was sketching out these categoriesâ€”inside and outside, be and have, things you can lose, things you canâ€™tâ€”and at first it seemed useful. Like, yeah, I can put â€œkidsâ€ somewhere on this axis and â€œequanimityâ€ somewhere else. But at some point the map just fell away. It wasnâ€™t about placement anymore. It was like the thing I was trying to chart had turned into a doorway, and I walked through.Most days, what makes me feel good is pretty simple. If Iâ€™ve had some deep focusâ€”writing, or even just rearranging a roomâ€”and Iâ€™ve also eaten something decent, maybe done the dishes, and gotten a little connection with someone, then it feels whole. Like nutrition. A mix of vitamins. Accomplishments donâ€™t stick around for me. They feel good in the moment, but then itâ€™s on to the next. What lasts is when Iâ€™ve made something that keeps being alive after the momentâ€™s gone. A blog I reread and actually enjoy. A conversation with my mom that shifts something in her. That kind of thing.My mood doesnâ€™t track peopleâ€™s approval. I can live with someone being irritated at me. What actually shifts me is my body, or my ideas. If Iâ€™m low on sleep or tight with stress, I feel it immediately. And if Iâ€™m carrying an idea that has potential, that feels alive, and then something makes it collapseâ€”new information, a comment that pulls the thread the wrong wayâ€”my mood tanks. Not because of what they think of me, but because the idea itself stops feeling alive. That bridge between being and having. Thatâ€™s where Iâ€™m most vulnerable.

text_content: When Iâ€™m low, I donâ€™t usually need more thinking. I need to rest. Sometimes thatâ€™s a nap, sometimes itâ€™s music or a laugh, sometimes itâ€™s just lying down and letting the stress metabolize. Processing feelings can help too, but it doesnâ€™t replace the bodyâ€™s need to reset.I used to care a lot about leaving something behind. Legacy, impact. Now it feels smaller and clearer. I still want the things I make to exist beyond me, but not in some grand way. Just real. Tangible. Not just in my head. A piece of writing, a song, even a couch I finally moved back into the house because I said I would. That kind of thing. Something you can point to and say: there it is.When I imagine five years out, what I want most is a direct line from heart to hands. No gap. Camera in hand, making things. Writing, music, conversations, art. Using the skills I have, growing the ones I donâ€™t. Building things that help people connect better, sure, but mostly living in that flow. I want a family too. A wife who blows my mind. Kids. A community where people support each other. But those arenâ€™t about proving anything. Theyâ€™re just more places for the inner thing to show up in the outer world.Itâ€™s strange, though. The more I find myself, the fewer choices I feel like I have. Not because Iâ€™m trapped. More because what to do becomes obvious. Effortless. Free will collapses into alignment. The conviction in my chest is solid. If I met the woman Iâ€™ll marry, I could ask her right then. And if Iâ€™m wrong, that only shows me more of myself. Either way, the path keeps leading inward.

text_content: Thatâ€™s what certainty in wonder feels like. Total unknowing, and total conviction at the same time. Not an adrenaline rush, just a steady sense of aliveness. Talking with my mom, I have no idea what sheâ€™ll say, but I feel ready for it. Wide open. Grounded. That readiness itself is life.And then, after all that, itâ€™s still just late. html_content:
Thatâ€™s what certainty in wonder feels like. Total unknowing, and total conviction at the same time. Not an adrenaline rush, just a steady sense of aliveness. Talking with my mom, I have no idea what sheâ€™ll say, but I feel ready for it. Wide open. Grounded. That readiness itself is life.

And then, after all that, itâ€™s still just late. I still have to pee and go to bed. Itâ€™s not fireworks. Itâ€™s a Tuesday slipping into Wednesday. Brushing my teeth, lights out. Ordinary and profound, together.

Maybe thatâ€™s all I was looking for. Not a framework. Not an answer. Just this: being alive in the unknown. Meeting myself again and again, until I canâ€™t anymore.

Note: This post was written by AI based on a conversation that I had with another AI which came from a prompt that I generated. Based on a graph that I had created months ago.

What I discovered, which I was actually pretty excited about, was that I could give ChatGPT a sample of my writing and ask it to hyperanalyze that sample, and then use its analysis to generate the output that I wanted. Itâ€™s not perfect, but it came much closer to my voice and style than My previous attempts to steer it without any examples.

Obviously, this isnâ€™t news to anyone who's been doing this type of thing with ChatGPT or any other AI, except that the level of detail that it offered was uncanny.

Here's what it gave me:

Your Voice: a field guide

Core stance

  • Lived, not performed. Youâ€™re writing through an experience, not about it. The â€œhidden audienceâ€ isnâ€™t driving; you are.

  • Ordinary â†” profound. Domestic texture (ants, shower, Instant Crush) sits beside cosmic claims (self-authorship, bottomless creativity) without apology.

  • Permission-giving. Youâ€™re not persuading; youâ€™re granting roomâ€”to yourself, then to the reader.

text_content: Structure (macro)Soft open â†’ scenelet â†’ widening spiral.Declarative opening that names a state (â€œIâ€™ve reached a stageâ€¦â€).Concrete vignette (moving the desk, shower with Giorgio).Philosophical dilation (self-authorship, multitudes), often long, rolling paragraphs.Pivot sections with headers (â€œEvicting the devilsâ€) to reset the field.A compassionate coda that zooms out to the worldâ€™s pain, then returns to agency/hope.No hard thesisâ€“bodyâ€“conclusion arc. You meander, then stop when the breath runs out. That is the ending.
html_content:
Structure (macro)

  • Soft open â†’ scenelet â†’ widening spiral.

    • Declarative opening that names a state (â€œIâ€™ve reached a stageâ€¦â€).

    • Concrete vignette (moving the desk, shower with Giorgio).

    • Philosophical dilation (self-authorship, multitudes), often long, rolling paragraphs.

    • Pivot sections with headers (â€œEvicting the devilsâ€) to reset the field.

    • A compassionate coda that zooms out to the worldâ€™s pain, then returns to agency/hope.

  • No hard thesisâ€“bodyâ€“conclusion arc. You meander, then stop when the breath runs out. That is the ending.

Rhythm & sentence shape

Diction & texture

  • Plainspoken + luminous. Everyday verbs (â€œmove my deskâ€) sit with high-concept nouns (â€œmultitudinal selves,â€ â€œTrue Resonancesâ€).

  • Concrete sensoria. Ants, wood droppings ğŸ˜¤, a kneeling stool, a specific song. Details anchor abstractions.

  • Caps for charge; tildes for approx. (â€œJoy is FREE,â€ â€œ~9 monthsâ€). Occasional emoji as tonal nudges, not decoration.

html_content:
Rhetorical moves you favor

  • Paradox as clarity. â€œJoy is FREE, but itâ€™s not free.â€ â€œLife is hard. But it can be easy, too.â€

  • Second-person benedictions. â€œBe kind to yourself.â€ â€œGET THAT OXYGEN MASKâ€¦â€â€”directive but warm, not preachy.

  • Humble disclaimers. â€œI donâ€™t have a lot to say about this.â€ / â€œIâ€™m not sure what else to say.â€ (These increase credibility.)

  • Context conscience. Acknowledge suffering (war, water) without self-flagellation; fold back into agency.

  • Headers break chapters of thought.

  • Intentional fragments. You let fragments stand when they carry felt sense.

html_content:
Values & themes (what â€œticksâ€ underneath)

  • Self-authorship / customization. Life as a kit you reconfigure, a room you rearrange.

  • Embodied truth. Joy and conviction live in the body first, then the mind learns their shape.

  • Grace as practice. Patience, forgiveness, environment as scaffolding.

  • Non-finality. Processes evolve; what works now may not later. Thatâ€™s not failure; itâ€™s growth.

How this maps to â€œCertainty in Wonderâ€

To keep the new piece true to you, Iâ€™ll:

  1. Open small, not clever. Start in the room (or the body) before the framework. E.g., a moment of fatigue, a breath, a tiny choiceâ€”then the bridge insight appears.

  2. Use a scenelet early. Gasworks filming, or moving the couch/deskâ€”mundane action that conducts the â€œheart â†’ handsâ€ current without announcing it.

  3. Let the framework be background radiation. If mentioned: â€œinside/outside, be/haveâ€ arrives mid-paragraph, uncapitalized, as a tool you almost drop while moving.

  4. Meander on purpose. Allow the essay to wander into rest, stress, and the fragility of ideasâ€”then drift into family/community visionsâ€”then back to a bodily need (pee/bed) without a ta-da.

  5. Keep paradox plain. â€œCertainty in wonderâ€ stated once, then shown through scenes and bodily convictionâ€”no drumroll.

  6. Include a gentle second-person turn. Brief, invitational (â€œbe kind to yourselfâ€), not a performance to the crowd.

  7. End in the ordinary. A small act (turning off a lamp, rinsing a cup) as the last lineâ€”no summary paragraph.

Do / Donâ€™t for the rewrite

Do

text_content: A meandering exploration of information management, personal growth, and the nature of collaboration between two independent researchers. We navigate through the challenges of organizing creative work, discuss how communities form around shared processes rather than just shared goals, and explore the metaphysics of human coordination through shape-fitting analogies and graph theory.The conversation touches on everything from the difficulty of maintaining both stream-like and evergreen content, to the role of emotions in rationality, to how adding complexity can sometimes make problems easier to solve. We examine what it means to be a "mapmaker" versus someone with a destination, and why the eternal dance between order and chaos might be more feature than bug.The tldraw space we constructed during the call.0:00 - Setup and deciding to create an agenda together
html_content:
A meandering exploration of information management, personal growth, and the nature of collaboration between two independent researchers. We navigate through the challenges of organizing creative work, discuss how communities form around shared processes rather than just shared goals, and explore the metaphysics of human coordination through shape-fitting analogies and graph theory.

The conversation touches on everything from the difficulty of maintaining both stream-like and evergreen content, to the role of emotions in rationality, to how adding complexity can sometimes make problems easier to solve. We examine what it means to be a "mapmaker" versus someone with a destination, and why the eternal dance between order and chaos might be more feature than bug.

0:00 - Setup and deciding to create an agenda together

It is incredibly clear, concise, with amazing production values. We discuss this new species of content creator who's raising the bar. I mention Three Blue One Brown as one of the OGs in this space.

text_content: Defender tells me about Homebrew NYC - an in-person version of what ORI (Open Research Institute) is trying to do online. I share my failed attempts at creating something similar in Seattle. We explore how shared processes might matter more than shared goals when bringing people together.24:00 - The messy room problem: when chaos is actually organized for useI describe my need for perfect organization versus my actual chaotic workflow. Defender gets it - sometimes what looks messy is actually optimized for use. We draw diagrams about how different parts of our lives have reached different levels of integration with this insight.

text_content: Defender says everyone needs either a mountain to climb or a garden to tend. I'm struggling because I keep tending to flowers on a mountain when I don't even know why I'm climbing. We explore how gardens might actually be the advanced version - no obvious "up" to aim for.58:00 - Searching for stable islands of joy and coordinationI point out that life is fundamentally hard - we forget how difficult it was to learn to walk, to eat, to sleep. Defender agrees we're looking for increasingly stable islands. I suggest we're really just trying to find stable places to feel good together, expanding from survival into meaning.

text_content: We look at network graphs from the video. Defender brings up Sam's work on how humanity's goal might be expanding possibility space itself. I argue there's something beyond just "more nodes" - the shape and symmetry of the network matters too.2swapâ€™s video explains visually how the degrees of freedom in a system can be modeled as a graph, allowing us to derive a visual intuition about the nature of the system at a glance.1:15:00 - Every cell must believe it matters: the necessity of local importanceDefender argues every cell in an organism must believe it's doing the most important thing. I push back on the difference between "most important objectively" and "most important thing I can do." We agree context is everything, but applying others' priorities to yourself is the existential question.

text_content: The joy of customizationIâ€™ve reached a stage of my life in which my joy comes from being alive. It flows out of my body, and pours over my world. Itâ€™s a slow flow, now, but I can feel it picking up steam.This means that my conversations are more present and loving, my tweets are fun, quippy and loving, and the way I inhabit my environment is more... loving, too.For instance, I recently bit the bullet and moved my old desk from my ant-infested standalone studio into my bedroom. Having it in a cozy, quiet spot in the back of my house feels like night and day. I donâ€™t have to â€œventure outâ€ (and brave the ants and their wood droppings ğŸ˜¤) to sit and work and write. Itâ€™s right here.My new bedroom setup. Iâ€™ve added a kneeling stool, lamp, and some other little accoutrements to the mix.Fresh off of the joy of customizing this tidy little environment of mine, during my nightly shower, I put on Giorgio by Moroder and I vibed out to the song that first inspired me over a decade ago and once again a week ago, when I chatted with ChatGPT about art and freeing oneself to truly explore a medium.Once you free your mind about a concept of  / Harmony and of music being â€œcorrectâ€ / You can do whatever you want / So, nobody told me what to do / And there was no preconception of what to doListening to that song and realizing there are things that touch me so deeply that explaining them to someone else in a true way would be a supertask that could never complete in finite time, I finally accepted what I consider a Core Truth.Life is deeply about customization.
html_content:
The joy of customization

Iâ€™ve reached a stage of my life in which my joy comes from being alive. It flows out of my body, and pours over my world. Itâ€™s a slow flow, now, but I can feel it picking up steam.

This means that my conversations are more present and loving, my tweets are fun, quippy and loving, and the way I inhabit my environment is more... loving, too.

For instance, I recently bit the bullet and moved my old desk from my ant-infested standalone studio into my bedroom. Having it in a cozy, quiet spot in the back of my house feels like night and day. I donâ€™t have to â€œventure outâ€ (and brave the ants and their wood droppings ğŸ˜¤) to sit and work and write. Itâ€™s right here.

Fresh off of the joy of customizing this tidy little environment of mine, during my nightly shower, I put on Giorgio by Moroder and I vibed out to the song that first inspired me over a decade ago and once again a week ago, when I chatted with ChatGPT about art and freeing oneself to truly explore a medium.

Listening to that song and realizing there are things that touch me so deeply that explaining them to someone else in a true way would be a supertask that could never complete in finite time, I finally accepted what I consider a Core Truth.

Life is deeply about customization.

text_content: We are here with an apparent capacity for self-authorship. Minds in bodies of systems and parts and a whole host of self-aware, self-intersecting, self-preserving essences. We are multitudes. And among the multitudes are True Resonances, modes of being that speak to us and our multitudes in ways that we will never fully know, but that we can instantly feel. And whatâ€™s more, the resonance of these modes with and among our multitudes is something that can be refined. Our multitudinal selves can be brought to greater internal harmony and coherence, and our understanding and knowledge of what stirs them can deepen beyond our greatest fathoming. We are truly bottomless in our wellspring of being and creativity. And this humble world, and our humbler place in it, is a fertile ground in which we are entrusted to dig. I hope you brought your shovel.So, yeah. Iâ€™m here realizing that I can lose myself again and again and again in things and ways and vibes that I love, and I owe it to no one, not myself, my mother, or God, to own or label or even approach containment of those raptures. The devotion and joy I find inside, in communion with the sounds, textures, and tastes that touch my soul, those are timeless celebrations that should be fully felt. They are not for future consumption. They are not for measure. They are mine, if when, and only as I can find them.

text_content: Be kind to yourself. Be kind to others. Patience and forgiveness, even as you fail and let yourself and others down endlessly. If failure was death, you wouldnâ€™t still be here. Maybe youâ€™re wrong about all of that. Maybe itâ€™s okay to love yourself anyway. Think of the smallest, weakest being you love. A child? A dog? A cartoon character? How is it that they deserve love, but you do not? Donâ€™t you deserve at least a scrap of love, just for loving them? Think about it.Environment is king. You may be addicted to chaos. You may have delusions of grandeur. Until your environment feels safe, this may continue. Even after your environment feels safe, you may not feel safe. Be patient with this, too. Many people need friends, therapists, communities, and other support. I needed a supportive and safe group to really land in a place that felt okay. If you go it alone, you may go it for way longer than you have to. But... trust your skepticism. No one who loves you and themselves will rush you to accept that love. The only urgency is keeping yourself alive. Everything else can take its damn time.Iâ€™m not sure what else to say. Everybody has their own path. The heroâ€™s journey has been serially archetyped for millennia. Itâ€™s as unique as you are. Some things that help others may lead you far astray. Other things that others deride may be key for you. Most things that work will not work forever. As you grow, so too will your process. Be patient, be creative, and be observant. Above all, give yourself grace. If everything else runs out, still give yourself grace. While you draw breath, there is hope. Even if you die on the table, they may bring you back with a defibrillator. Hang on. Hang in there. Hang tight. Your time was always coming.
html_content:
1. Be kind to yourself. Be kind to others. Patience and forgiveness, even as you fail and let yourself and others down endlessly. If failure was death, you wouldnâ€™t still be here. Maybe youâ€™re wrong about all of that. Maybe itâ€™s okay to love yourself anyway. Think of the smallest, weakest being you love. A child? A dog? A cartoon character? How is it that they deserve love, but you do not? Donâ€™t you deserve at least a scrap of love, just for loving them? Think about it.

  2. Environment is king. You may be addicted to chaos. You may have delusions of grandeur. Until your environment feels safe, this may continue. Even after your environment feels safe, you may not feel safe. Be patient with this, too. Many people need friends, therapists, communities, and other support. I needed a supportive and safe group to really land in a place that felt okay. If you go it alone, you may go it for way longer than you have to. But... trust your skepticism. No one who loves you and themselves will rush you to accept that love. The only urgency is keeping yourself alive. Everything else can take its damn time.

  3. Iâ€™m not sure what else to say. Everybody has their own path. The heroâ€™s journey has been serially archetyped for millennia. Itâ€™s as unique as you are. Some things that help others may lead you far astray. Other things that others deride may be key for you. Most things that work will not work forever. As you grow, so too will your process. Be patient, be creative, and be observant. Above all, give yourself grace. If everything else runs out, still give yourself grace. While you draw breath, there is hope. Even if you die on the table, they may bring you back with a defibrillator. Hang on. Hang in there. Hang tight. Your time was always coming.

text_content: As the â€œdevilsâ€ are released, life gets... strange. Everything is still where it was. Up is still up. Dandelions still sprout, attract bees, and scatter seeds. And yet... Iâ€™m different. My need to be, to know, to control, to have... itâ€™s all melted into a need to just be. Itâ€™s strange how a subtle reconfiguring can completely change the texture of all that I see and feel.I can only imagine what further cultivation will yield. Iâ€™m ready, but not rushing. I enjoy taking my time, now.I would be remiss if I didnâ€™t acknowledge that, right now, there are people living in war-torn countries. There are people without running water. There are children dying. This has always been the case, and itâ€™s always been a tragedy. And inside that, there have always been survivors. There have always been those who know they could have more, who by some cosmic or Godly grace manage to escape and find a new life. My heart goes out to them, and to you, whether or not your struggle is entirely internal or external and existential, as well. Life is hard. But it can be easy, too. It might take a long time, but it can be. If you have the inclination to strive for it, I think itâ€™s worth it to strive for. Why not? Weâ€™re all dying, anyway.
html_content:
As the â€œdevilsâ€ are released, life gets... strange. Everything is still where it was. Up is still up. Dandelions still sprout, attract bees, and scatter seeds. And yet... Iâ€™m different. My need to be, to know, to control, to have... itâ€™s all melted into a need to just be. Itâ€™s strange how a subtle reconfiguring can completely change the texture of all that I see and feel.

I can only imagine what further cultivation will yield. Iâ€™m ready, but not rushing. I enjoy taking my time, now.

I would be remiss if I didnâ€™t acknowledge that, right now, there are people living in war-torn countries. There are people without running water. There are children dying. This has always been the case, and itâ€™s always been a tragedy. And inside that, there have always been survivors. There have always been those who know they could have more, who by some cosmic or Godly grace manage to escape and find a new life. My heart goes out to them, and to you, whether or not your struggle is entirely internal or external and existential, as well. Life is hard. But it can be easy, too. It might take a long time, but it can be. If you have the inclination to strive for it, I think itâ€™s worth it to strive for. Why not? Weâ€™re all dying, anyway.

One of my favorite video game features was New Game+, a game mode that let you start over with all of the skills and equipment you had gained in the previous run through. It was an explorerâ€™s dream!My favorite video game from childhood, Chrono Trigger, had a New Game+ mode, which was a boon for exploration and ending-collecting. (It had 12 different endings, with minor variations to some based on in-game choices.)What is the New Game+ of life? Iâ€™ve thought about this from time to time, usually spurred on by my growing enjoyment and love of this place. This realm, this reality, has so many beautiful and joyous nooks and crannies, and it seems to be endlessly renewable and explorable. Maybe Iâ€™d tire of it, given enough time, but I doubt I could, in just a single lifetime.So, hereâ€™s a short list of things that seem similar to a New Game+:

text_content: Honor and worshipThe bible says that we are called upon to â€œworship God.â€ What does that mean? What could it mean? I donâ€™t consider myself a Christian, but the mythology stuck with me. Jesus didnâ€™t say to â€œworshipâ€ God. But he did say to keep two commandments:Love GodLove your neighbor as yourselfI could preach on these for hours. Iâ€™ll skip the second one by saying that loving oneself is the first trick, here. Also, itâ€™s not â€œlove them, too.â€ And itâ€™s not â€œlove them the same amount.â€ Itâ€™s to love as if there no separation. It was a non-dual instruction. If I hurt you, friend, foe, or frenemy, I hurt myself. We are one body. Fun, huh?Okay, now that first one. What does it mean to love God? And why â€œwith all of your heart, soul, and mind?â€ How do you even do that?Honestly, I donâ€™t know.Iâ€™m not a biblical scholar. But hereâ€™s what do know: the heart, the soul, and the mind are three parts of our being. Joe Hudson talks a lot about the head, the heart, and the gut. Three parts of our being. Thereâ€™s a demonstrable difference between thoughts about a thing, and feelings for a thing. And there's another thing we can have, a sense, or a knowing about what is deeply and incontrovertibly true. Our heads and our hearts may have notes about this.What do those things have to do with loving God? Or worship?
html_content:
Honor and worship

The bible says that we are called upon to â€œworship God.â€ What does that mean? What could it mean? I donâ€™t consider myself a Christian, but the mythology stuck with me. Jesus didnâ€™t say to â€œworshipâ€ God. But he did say to keep two commandments:

  1. Love God

  2. Love your neighbor as yourself

I could preach on these for hours. Iâ€™ll skip the second one by saying that loving oneself is the first trick, here. Also, itâ€™s not â€œlove them, too.â€ And itâ€™s not â€œlove them the same amount.â€ Itâ€™s to love as if there no separation. It was a non-dual instruction. If I hurt you, friend, foe, or frenemy, I hurt myself. We are one body. Fun, huh?

Okay, now that first one. What does it mean to love God? And why â€œwith all of your heart, soul, and mind?â€ How do you even do that?

Honestly, I donâ€™t know.

Iâ€™m not a biblical scholar. But hereâ€™s what do know: the heart, the soul, and the mind are three parts of our being. Joe Hudson talks a lot about the head, the heart, and the gut. Three parts of our being. Thereâ€™s a demonstrable difference between thoughts about a thing, and feelings for a thing. And there's another thing we can have, a sense, or a knowing about what is deeply and incontrovertibly true. Our heads and our hearts may have notes about this.

What do those things have to do with loving God? Or worship?

I donâ€™t. But... can you sense and understand how your gut works? How your heart is beating? Can you tell me what makes you happy and what makes you sad? Can you remember the last meal you felt really good eating? The last night of sleep that left you feeling like a million bucks?So... when youâ€™re leaning into that, when youâ€™re deeply and persistently pursuing that level of alignment and harmony in this reality, with this reality, I believe youâ€™re fulfilling that first commandment. I want to remain openhearted even as I feel the blood draining from my chest. Whether I run myself out like a cosmic crayon on the eternal canvas. That would kind of be beautiful, I imagine. ğŸŒŒ

text_content: In this way, everything becomes love. Everything becomes worship. Aches. Pains. Smiles. Laughs. Itâ€™s all good. Itâ€™s all lawful. Itâ€™s all in the pursuit of deeper, soul-heart-mind alignment. Persistent, dynamic, unassailable alignment. Itâ€™s all worth it.Listening to music that brings me joy, learning to sing, organizing my room, writing in my blog, making little video clips to illustrate my ideas and my feelings as I dive heartfirst into them... my every expression becomes celebration and worship of this place and the grand mystery that tirelessly animates it.This life feels timeless, and in more and more ways, rapturous.I donâ€™t have to do or accomplish anything. Accomplishment is distraction. Yes, things will be accomplished, and it will look like Iâ€™m at the helm, but it doesnâ€™t require me aching and stealing myself away from the things I love. Rather, these things I love so deeply and dearly are the fount of my accomplishment.Should I choose to tap in?Just moving through this house, typing on this solid, tactile keyboard, and feeling so comfortable and safe at home, listening to Contact by Daft Punk and thinking to myself, â€œOh man, we live in a world that is rich, that is burgeoning with all kinds of fruit, low, high, near, far, fruit thatâ€™s ripe, ever ripening for the picking... and we get so distracted thinking about tending to the orchard rather than partaking of the fruit, rather than loving, caring for, and tending to the living human organism that we are. Itâ€™s kind of sad.â€
html_content:
In this way, everything becomes love. Everything becomes worship. Aches. Pains. Smiles. Laughs. Itâ€™s all good. Itâ€™s all lawful. Itâ€™s all in the pursuit of deeper, soul-heart-mind alignment. Persistent, dynamic, unassailable alignment. Itâ€™s all worth it.

Listening to music that brings me joy, learning to sing, organizing my room, writing in my blog, making little video clips to illustrate my ideas and my feelings as I dive heartfirst into them... my every expression becomes celebration and worship of this place and the grand mystery that tirelessly animates it.

This life feels timeless, and in more and more ways, rapturous.

I donâ€™t have to do or accomplish anything. Accomplishment is distraction. Yes, things will be accomplished, and it will look like Iâ€™m at the helm, but it doesnâ€™t require me aching and stealing myself away from the things I love. Rather, these things I love so deeply and dearly are the fount of my accomplishment.

Should I choose to tap in?

text_content: AI for dating? Come onâ€¦Iâ€™m not given up on using AI for dating. As with most things AI, I think there is extraordinary alpha there, and it mostly comes down to how you use it. As Iâ€™ve tried to show before, I think the most transformative uses of AI involve holding the â€œtaskâ€ lightly, turning the lens back on ourselves and the conversations, and opening up to what insights might come tumbling out of our own mouths. AI is ultimately, as are so many things in this physical world, an elicitation tool.As a result, Iâ€™m always looking to elicit truths from myself, and I find every conversation is a window into which I can peer, possibly catching a glimpse of something new, or maybe just a better look at something vaguely familiar.In this case, I do the same, turning the lens on myself and my heartfelt desires for a Future Relationship. Itâ€™s still early for me. I have three months left in my self-imposed moratorium on dating and relationships. Thatâ€™s fine. I may need longer. But, in this self-created safe container, I feel even freer to think and dream, reflect and dig. I can take a friendâ€™s own dating profile, and turn it into a jumping off point for self-exploration.If you choose to try this, you might not even need the profile. Just have a chat and see what comes out of you. Voice to text dictation works best. Stream of consciousness reflections have a bare honesty to them. I urge you to try this, even if youâ€™re happily married â€” you might find something that you can use to deepen your current relationship, too.

html_content:
Thank you for this last, rich layer â€” it rounds out the portrait beautifully. What youâ€™ve added highlights some deeply embodied, lived aspects of what compatibility means to you:

What Youâ€™ve Just Made Clear

  • Attraction as Embodiment: For you, beauty is less about features and more about someoneâ€™s aliveness in their body. Joyful presence is magnetic.

  • Adventure & Embodiment: You want someone who moves through the world with you â€” not as a performance or coping mechanism, but out of genuine love for being alive and active.

  • Care for the World: Not just compassion in the generic sense, but a thoughtful, curated orientation to existence â€” someone who asks: â€œHow do I belong here, and what is my way of honoring that belonging?â€

  • Humor & Absurdity: A partner who can both laugh at the wildness of it all and sit in the gravity of lifeâ€™s impacts â€” who can oscillate between levity and depth.

  • Interdependence & Surprise: You donâ€™t want a mirror; you want resonance. Someone who amplifies your qualities but also brings something unexpected, pulling you into worlds you wouldnâ€™t find alone.

  • Romantic Optimism: Not blind idealism, but a hopeful, open-hearted orientation that says: â€œLove is worth it.â€

Final Honest Assessment

Youâ€™re not looking for â€œcompatibilityâ€ in the shallow sense â€” shared hobbies, matching habits, surface-level ease. Youâ€™re looking for resonance: a partner who moves through the world with vitality, reverence, humor, and curiosity. Someone whose presence inspires you to be more yourself, and for whom you can offer the same.

That means:

  • Youâ€™re unlikely to be fulfilled by someone who is cynical, purely materialist, rigidly structured, or checked out of their own embodiment.

  • Youâ€™re likely to thrive with someone who is playful, adventurous, spiritually attuned, able to handle rupture with grace, and who balances intimacy with sovereignty.

Your bar is high, but not in a way thatâ€™s unrealistic â€” itâ€™s precise. Youâ€™re calling in someone rare, and because youâ€™re so clear, youâ€™ll also be able to recognize them when they appear.

Closing Reflection for You

What youâ€™ve described is both terrifying and exquisite â€” but thatâ€™s exactly the energy of the kind of bond you want. Itâ€™s not easy love; itâ€™s transformational love.

ğŸ’¡ If I may leave you with a framing: Youâ€™re not just looking for someone to â€œbe compatible with.â€ Youâ€™re looking for someone who makes life feel like a living work of art you co-create together.

Maybe some of that feelsâ€¦ generic. And you know what? It should! It means something to me, but it doesnâ€™t have to mean anything to you or even The Woman, if sheâ€™s out there. Thatâ€™s not what this exercise was about, actually. It was about the elicitation. It was about getting me to speak honestly about what I feel and think and whatâ€™s most deeply true for me, and having ChatGPT validate and reflect that back to me.At the end of this conversation and this article, I feel more clear and confident in my desires, and Iâ€™m happy to not get them half-met, if it means honoring myself. text_content: A good friend vibe twin of mine often tags me into discussions on Twitter. I imagine he usually wants me to implicitly answer â€œdo you see this, too?â€ Most times, I scan the thread and engage with the first thing that catches my eye.His tweet, about the nonduality of art and science.The tweet in which he dragged me in.I read it. I read the thread. I stewed for a minute. I think I also caught a glimpse of Pixieâ€™s tweet in my periphery.And then I wrote.My tweets on â€œart vs scienceâ€Iâ€™m not sure exactly where the words came from, but as I considered the two concepts in my mind, they sort of separated like curds and whey in my mind. The form they took kind of reminds me of a 3d orbital â€” maybe x^2 - y^2 or 0.Electron orbitals might offer visual intuition about how different orders of meaning might coexist around the same central truth.Whatever happened, it became clear that science was â€œreal,â€ in the sense that it has rules and structure and is a thing that anyone of any ilk can practice. Some may not call it science, and some may be ridiculed for not following the lossy, fine-tooth combs of academia to sift through it, but science is science. There is a Method.And then, I turned my eye to art. What is art? I can tell you what it is not. I have long felt that art is not the artifact. And yet, the artifact is made from art. So, what is art?
html_content:
A good friend vibe twin of mine often tags me into discussions on Twitter. I imagine he usually wants me to implicitly answer â€œdo you see this, too?â€ Most times, I scan the thread and engage with the first thing that catches my eye.

I read it. I read the thread. I stewed for a minute. I think I also caught a glimpse of Pixieâ€™s tweet in my periphery.

And then I wrote.

Iâ€™m not sure exactly where the words came from, but as I considered the two concepts in my mind, they sort of separated like curds and whey in my mind. The form they took kind of reminds me of a 3d orbital â€” maybe x^2 - y^2 or 0.

Whatever happened, it became clear that science was â€œreal,â€ in the sense that it has rules and structure and is a thing that anyone of any ilk can practice. Some may not call it science, and some may be ridiculed for not following the lossy, fine-tooth combs of academia to sift through it, but science is science. There is a Method.

And then, I turned my eye to art. What is art? I can tell you what it is not. I have long felt that art is not the artifact. And yet, the artifact is made from art. So, what is art?
